Their business is continuing to grow, so Angelina is seeking a loan of 25,000 pesos to pay for raw materials including bamboo, rope, nails and other items needed to make furniture.  Angelina requests this loan so that she can sustain the growth of her business and be able to meet the increasing demands of her regular customers. Having this opportunity to receive a loan from Kiva through ASHI will provide a chance to achieve her ambition in life: To renovate her family's home, to earn a good living and to have the financial means to support her family and fund the college education of her children.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials to make bamboo furniture

loans.name: Beng

texts.en:
Mrs. C. is a 45-year-old widow. She works very hard as a fish seller in her village, and typically earns around $4 per day. She has four school-aged children who sometimes work as temporary laborers when they are free from studying. This provides a part of the income that supports the family.

C. leads her fish business more smoothly, there being many regular clients. She has had a goal to improve her business for a long time but she can’t do it because she doesn’t have the capital. Thus, C. is looking for assistance to help her to increase the financial capital of her fish-selling business.

loans.use: To increase the financial capital of her fish-selling business

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Mrs. Ros L., 57 years old, is a farmer who has four married children: two sons and two daughters. She lives on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Ros does not have enough capital to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm. So, she is asking for a loan of $300 to help her capital.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal U. and her husband, Mr. Leang Seak, have been married since 1990 and have one daughter who is in school. The family lives along National Road Number Six, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sophal has been selling food and rice for more than two years. Her husband has been driving a taxi for more than ten years as well, but his taxi breaks down and does not work well.

Hence, Sophal is asking for her second loan of $1,000 to repair her husband’s taxi. She will also use a part of her loan to put an addition on her house.

loans.use: To repair her husband’s taxi and put an addition on her house

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Thorn N. is a villager in Lvea Sa Kandal village in Kandal province and she was born in 1983. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband is a fisherman who is able to earn some money from selling fish to support his family. Her husband is on the left in the photo

Although this family tries to work hard, they earn a low income. Accordingly, they want to start a new business but they do not have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Thorn N. decided to ask for a loan to construct a pigsty for raising pigs. With the rest of the loan she wants to buy a battery for her husband's fishing business.

Mrs. Thorn N. is the mother of four children who are all enrolled in the local public school..

loans.use: To construct a pigsty for raising pigs plus a battery for her husband's fishing business

loans.name: Chie

texts.en:
Mrs. M., 70, is a married woman living in Phnom Penh. She is a crop grower and is also a good homemaker who currently stays at home to care for her children and do housework. She has three kids: two are studying and also work; another one is married and lives independently. She sometimes depends on her husband, who is a wooden-house building foreman, for income.

M. plants various kinds of vegetables that she will harvest and sell when they mature. She faces a problem in that she lacks some supplies to improve her crop. She is applying for money to buy seeds, fertilizer, insecticide for her crops.

From the loan M. is hopeful she will earn more money to ensure a good standard of living for her family.

loans.use: To buy seeds, fertilizer and insecticide

loans.name: Yoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoeurn T., who is a villager in Kor village in Kandal province, was born in 1972. She is a housewife and her husband is a motorbike repairer in the local village who is able to earn some money from this business. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

Since her husband’s business is going well, Mrs. Yoeurn T. wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to seek a loan to buy more motorbike supplies to sell.

Through this activity, they support two children, one of whom is enrolled in the local public school, while the other is too young to go to school or work.

loans.use: To buy more motorbike supplies to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
As a busy entrepreneur, Myrna has been running a sari-sari (variety) store for almost four years. Her husband, Danilo, is a carpenter in the neighborhood.

To build her business, Myrna would like to receive a loan of 30,000 PHP to increase the inventory of goods sold in her sari-sari store and to support her secondary business of hog-fattening. She is planning to purchase additional products such as rice, sugar, gasoline, eggs, and other supplies, and feed for the hogs. She believes that offering a wide assortment of goods to customers will increase traffic to her store and maintain customer loyalty in their village.

Since 2005, Myrna has been a committed member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva micro-finance partner in the Philippines. She has been a model member with a 100% credit rating on her previous loans from ASHI.

Myrna’s long-term goals are to provide a better future for her family, sustain the profitability of her store, and start a savings account for her children’s education. Through hard work and determination, she is focused on improving her quality of life with the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products for her sari-sari store and feed for her hogs

loans.name: Theary

texts.en:
Mrs. Theary M. is a villager in Chek village in Kandal province and she was born in 1972. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice to sell for supporting herself and her family.

In the rice field, Mrs. Theary M. now faces some problems because her field has infertile soil and it is far from the irrigation system. Thus, in order to improve her production of rice, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline for her water pump.

Mrs. Theary M. is single and lives in a household of five members.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Khy

texts.en:
Mrs. Khy L. lives in Kor village in Kandal province and she is 33 years old. She is a farmer who owns 2-hectares (5-acres) of land on which she cultivates rice to sell to support her family. Her husband is a furniture maker in the local village who is able to earn a low income. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

The couple try to work hard but still are able to earn less income than needed. So they want to start a new business but they do not have money to do so. Thus, Mrs. Khy L. decided to ask for a loan to buy a sow for breeding. With the rest of the loan she wants to buy a wood-cutting machine.

Mrs. Khy L. is the mother of three children, one of whom is enrolled in a garment factory, while the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy a sow to breed

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal N., 29 (pictured here) and her husband, Mr. Sam-ang Heang, 30, have been married since 2007 and just have a young daughter. The family lives on an Island in the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 
Sophal has been operating grocery store for a year. She buys grocery items from Phnom Penh market and sells in front of her house. She is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to purchase additional grocery items for her stock.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items for her stock

loans.name: Luy

texts.en:
Mrs. Luy P., 67, sells grilled bananas to earn a living and lives with her husband and four children who are students. From her business she is able to generate $5 each day to cover the financial problems of her family. One of her kids is working as a chef for weddings.

Luy P.’s husband, Mr. Moul Phat, is a fish-seller who goes to buy the fish from his wholesale suppliers who are fishermen at the river. Her husband complains he always pays a lot of money for fish delivery fees and has a goal to have a vehicle so that he can cut down on hiring fees.

Therefore, Luy P. requests a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband to pick up the fish from the river to sell at the market.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband's fish-selling business

loans.name: Girlie

texts.en:
Girlie A., 30, is making sure that her family has enough provision for their daily needs. Married to Renante, a driver, she is blessed with a child in their marriage. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  She has been managing her own fish stall while also operating a small variety store and a clothing store. She also operates a jeepney (small bus) which is being driven everyday by her husband.

Girlie has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings* and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow quite a few times in CCT’s cooperative.  She is consistent in paying her dues because she used the money she borrowed to expand and improve her businesses.     

To ensure the success of her businesses, Girlie would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be used as a source of added capital for her expanding businesses by buying more products to be incorporated into her current product inventories.

Girlie dreams that her businesses will continue to grow so that she can provide for her children’s education. She also wants to see her businesses grow into much more stable and successful businesses than they are now.


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of fifteen to thirty community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more products to incorporate into her various inventories

loans.name: Sok Heng

texts.en:
Mr. Sok Heng P. and his wife are farmers who own 0.5 hectares (1.25 acres) of land on which they cultivate rice to support their family. In their rice field, they have some problems because their field has infertile soil and it is far from the irrigation system. Thus, in order to improve their production of rice, he decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and fuel for his water pump.

Mr. Sok Heng P. is the father of five children, one of whom is a laborer, while the others are attending the local public school. They all live in Kor village in Kandal province.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and fuel

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal L., 28, has been married since 2005 and has two children: one son and one daughter. She lives with her widowed mother on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Sophal has been a silk weaver since she was 18 years old. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. She is asking for a loan of $400 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Thearith

texts.en:
Mrs. Thearith K., 30, and her husband, Mr. Pov Meas, 41, have been married since 1997 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. Two of them are in school and the other two are still young. Her husband is a security guard and the family lives on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Thearith has been selling groceries since 2008; she buys grocery items from the market located in Phnom Penh for resale in the local market. She hopes to expand her business by buying more grocery items for her inventory. She is asking for a loan of $1,000 to add to her capital.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items to sell

loans.name: Phann

texts.en:
Mr. Phann P., is 51 year-old and his wife, Mrs. Kimsok Hoeung, is 51 years old. They have been married since 1985 and have six children: three sons and three daughters. One of them is married and lives outside the family home, three have full-time employment and the other two are in school. The family lives in a small village off of National Road Number Two, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Phann was not available for the photo so his wife is shown instead.

Phann has been a construction contractor for ten years while his wife stays at home and does housework. He is requesting a loan of $600 to renovate the house where he lives.

loans.use: To renovate the house where he lives

loans.name: Sokha

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokha A. is a villager in Lvea Sa Kandal village in Kandal province and she is 32 years old. She is a Khmer cake seller in the local village and her husband, Mr. Doeun Kuy, is a fisherman who is able to earn some money from selling fish to support his family. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

Now, they have some problems because their boat is too old to use but they do not have money to solve the problem. Thus, Mrs. Sokha A. decided to ask for a loan to buy a boat. The rest of the loan she wants to use to buy timber for construction of her home.

Mrs. Sokha A. is the mother of a child who is two years old.

loans.use: To buy a boat for her husband to use for fishing and also timber to construct her home

loans.name: Phos

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Phos and her husband, Mr. Sienghour Try, have been married since 2008 and just have a young son. They live with their parents in a small village off of National Road Number Two, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

S. and her husband operate a business moving earth, sand and sandstone for people. She is asking for her second loan of 400 USD to provide a new wheel for her husband’s truck.

loans.use: To provide a new wheel for her husband’s truck

loans.name: Tita

texts.en:
49-year-old Tita G. is a widow who works hard in her business to gain profit to support the financial needs of her seven children. Her eldest, who is 21 years old, has not been able to pursue her education in college due to Tita’s small income which is sometimes not even enough to support the needs of her six remaining children whose ages range from 8 to 19.

Despite her failure to graduate her eldest child from college, Tita is still hopeful that, by growing her business making and selling “bandi” (sweet peanut delicacy), her profit will increase as well. Then she would be able to support her children’s education, especially her second child who is now in her second year. In two more years she will be graduating and hopefully will have a better career in the near future.

“Bandi” is one of the most popular delicacies of Antique province and tourists buy it as a present. Demand for this product is increasing as the province industrializes. Tita wished to have large amount of capital to increase her production, thus meeting the demands of her customers.

With that, Tita is hereby requesting a much larger amount of loan through ASHI and, with that amount, she wishes to expand her market coverage. She is also hoping that she will be able to have more vendors in different places to increase her turnover.

loans.use: To purchase a large volume of ingredients for "bandi" production

loans.name: Samol

texts.en:
Mrs. Samol P. is 55 years old and lives in Lvea Sa Leu village in Kandal province. She is a food seller who is able to earn some money from this business to support her family.

Since her business is going well, Mrs. Samol P. wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy food stand supplies for selling food.

Mrs. Samol P. is a widow with two children who are all seamstresses in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy food stand supplies for selling rice

loans.name: Norn

texts.en:
Mrs. Norn P. (in the photo), 45, and her husband, Mr. Phearom Ream, 52, have been married since 1986 and have three children: two sons who attend school and one daughter who weaves silk at home. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Norn has been a silk weaver since she was 16 years old, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. Her husband is a farmer. She is asking for a loan of US$ 600 to purchase silk materials for her and her daughter’s weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her weaving business

loans.name: Chuon

texts.en: Mr. Chuon C. is a villager in Kamnab village in Kandal province and he was born in 1977. He is a construction worker and his wife, Mrs. Sothea Nhel, is a farmer who owns 2 hectares of land to cultivate rice on to support her family. Now they are facing an obstacle because their house is too old to live in, but they do not have money to repair it. Thus, in order to improve  family living conditions, Mr. Chuon C. decided to apply for a loan to construct a new house instead of the old one. He is the father of three children, two of whom are enrolled in local public school, while the other is only five years old. His wife is also in the photo.

loans.use: To construct a house

loans.name: Shina

texts.en:
Mrs. Shina C. lives in Preak Ta Choar village in Kandal province and she was born in 1960. She is a vegetable seller in the local market who earns some money to support her family. Since her business is going well she wants to expand it, but she does not have the money. Thus, Mrs. Shina C. decided to apply for a loan to buy more vegetables. With the rest of the loan, she wants to buy a trailer for selling vegetables. 

Her husband, Mr. Boeurn Aum, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice on to support his family. She is the mother of a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to sell and a trailer to sell out of

loans.name: Penh

texts.en:
Mr. Penh S. is 53 years old and he lives in Angk village in Kandal province. He is a government worker who can only get a low salary to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Man Yorn, is a farmer who owns 3.571 hectares of land to cultivate rice on to support her family. 

Now they have a problem because it is the right time to do farming on their rice field in the dry season, but they did not have money to do this. Thus, Mr. Penh S. decided to ask for a loan to do farming in this current year. He is the father of three children of whom all are attending local public school. His wife is also in the photo.

loans.use: To do dry season farming

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Mrs. Heng P. is a villager in Chambak Trab village in Kandal province and she was born in 1965. She is a farmer who owns 0.3 hectares of land to cultivate rice on to support her family. She farms and after that she has free time. According to this activity, she wants to start a new business but she does not have enough money. 

Thus, Mrs. Heng P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Vany Thom, is a motorbike taxi driver and she has five children, one of whom is a construction worker, while two others are enrolled in local public school, and the others are too young to go to school or work. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en: Mrs. Vanna M. is a widow who lives in Boeng Kaek village in Kandal province. She was born in 1971 and she is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land to grow rice on to support her family. She has some problems because her house is too old to live in. Thus, in order to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Vanna M. decided to ask for a loan to buy materials such as timbers to reconstruct her house. She has a child who is a seamstress in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy timbers to reconstruct her house

loans.name: Roem

texts.en: Mrs. Roem S. is a widow with two children who are seamstresses in a garment factory. She and her family live in Pratheat-VB village in Kandal province and she was born in 1948. She is a farmer who owns 0.7 hectares of land to cultivate rice to support her family. She has a problem because her house is dark and so is difficult to live in. Thus, in order to improve her family's living conditions, Mrs. Roem S. decided to seek a loan to buy an electric machine.

loans.use: To buy an electric machine

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. Mao P., a villager in Chambak Trab village in Kandal province, was born in 1948. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice on to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Nang Yiv, is a construction worker who can earn some money to support his family, too. 

Her family has a problem because her husband’s work place is far from their home. Thus, Mrs. Mao P. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband to ride to work. She is the mother of a child who is attending local public school. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en:
Rosalyn M. comes from a family who does fishing and fish-selling as a business. She is a widow who faces the challenge of giving her only child a better life, alone at her young age (35 years old). Adrian, her son and her life, is now 10 years old and is in elementary school. Because of him and the support of her family members, Rosalyn is inspired to work hard for her small fish-selling business to make it grow and become stable. Profits from this business will support her ambition of allowing her son to pursue his education until he graduates from college.  

Presently, Rosalyn is requesting a loan which will be used to purchase materials to repair her family’s fishing boat. In her family’s fishing business she will be given a share which will enable her to increase her revenue and have savings for the future of her only child.

loans.use: To purchase materials to repair a fishing boat.

loans.name: Srey Pao

texts.en: Mrs. Srey Pao S. and her husband, Mr. Phat Thon, are villagers in Check village in Kandal province and she was born in 1979. She is a farmer who owns 1 hectare of land to cultivate rice on to support her family. In the rice field, she has some problems because her field has infertile soil and it is far from the irrigation system. Thus, in order to improve rice production, Mrs. Srey Pao S. decided to apply for a loan to buy fertilizer and fuel. Her husband is a construction worker and she has a child who is one year old. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and fuel

loans.name: Seib

texts.en: In Check village in Kandal province lives a person who is Mrs. Seib S.. She was born in 1964 and she is a widow with a child who is a laborer in a local village. She is a farmer who owns a very small piece of land to cultivate rice on to support her family. In the rice field, she has some problems because her field is infertile and it is far from the irrigation system. Thus, in order to improve rice production, Mrs. Seib S. decided to request a loan to buy fertilizer and fuel for doing farming.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and fuel for farming

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap K. (pictured here), age 47, and her husband, Mr. Hoy Horm, 37, have been married since 1980 and have five children: two sons and three daughters. Two of them are garment factory workers. The family lives along National Road Number One about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. 

Sopheap and her husband have been farming for 20 years. They grow many kinds of vegetables on their farmland in the village. Sopheap is asking for her first loan of US$ 300 to build a toilet for family use.

loans.use: To build a toilet for family use

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Bernadette is 44 years-old and married with three children, she lives with her family in the province of Rizal in the Philippines.  Her husband Geronimo operates their tricycle business (motorcycle with a sidecar).   To supply additional income for her family, Bernadette is expanding the family business of Avon dealership which has been in operation for almost ten years.

Bernadette would like to receive a loan of 40,000 PHP to purchase an inventory of Avon products including lotions, lipsticks, bras, underwear, perfumes, cologne and other supplies.  As a dedicated member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 1999, Bernadette is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams.  Bernadette also has been a model member in the branch of Rizal Central Branch demonstrating regular attendance at weekly meetings and steady repayments on previous loans.  

With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that her expanded business will generate steady income to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of life to bring them far away from the cycle of poverty.  Bernadette hopes to diversify her revenue in the long term by supporting the maintenance of her secondary business endeavors including her husband’s tricycle business. 

Bernadette’s dreams are for her two youngest children to complete college.  Additionally, she hopes to continue business as a sustainable livelihood to support her family.

loans.use: To purchase an inventory of Avon products including lotions, lipsticks, bras, underwear, perfumes, cologne, etc.

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Sopheap Y. (in the photo), and her husband, Mr. Vuthy Khoem, live along National Road Number One about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2005 and have two young sons.

The couple has been farming for more than ten years; they grow rice and green beans on their farmland in the village. The couple hopes to continue increasing their productivity; farming is the main business to support their standard of living. Hence Sopheap is requesting her second loan of $500 to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain her farm.

loans.use: For seed, fertilizer, and pesticides

loans.name: Toung

texts.en: Mr. Toung E., a resident of Srae Ampil village in Kandal Province, was born in 1972 and has five children, four of whom are enrolled in local public school, while the youngest is only two years old. Toung is a farmer who owns a plot of land upon which he grows vegetables for sale to support his family. Toung's farm is currently infertile and it is far from an irrigation systE., so in order to improve his productivity he is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and gasoline. His wife, Mrs. Srey Mom Chom, shown on the right in the photo, is a soup seller in the village.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and gasoline

loans.name: Darun

texts.en: Mr. Darun S., 24 and his wife, Mrs. Pisey Tep, 29, have been married since 2007 and have a young daughter. The family lives along National Road Number One about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.  Darun has been driving a motor taxi for three years, while his wife stays at home and does housework. He hopes to better organize his house and so is asking for his first loan of $700 to renovate it. The photo shows his wife, as Darun was not available.

loans.use: To renovate his house

loans.name: Phouk

texts.en:
Mr. Phouk K., who lives in Samraong village in Kandal Province, was born in 1951. He and his wife, Mrs. Sun Heng Ros, are teachers in the local village school, and he also owns a very small piece of land upon which he grows fruit for sale to support his family. Because his family lacks sufficient access to water, Phouk is requesting a loan to dig a well for their use.

Phouk is a father of four children, one of whom is a goldsmith, while the others are enrolled in local public school. His wife is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To dig a well for his family’s use

loans.name: Saroun

texts.en:
Mr. Saroun L., 38, lives in Lvea Sar Kraom village in Kandal Province where he is a teacher in the local school. His wife, Mrs. Sokhoeurn Chou, is a vegetable and fruit seller in the local market who earns some money to help support her family. Since his wife’s business is doing well, Saroun is requesting a loan to buy more mangoes for re-selling and a trailer to transport them to market.

Saroun is the father of four children, one an NGO employee, another a farmer, and the others students in local public school. His wife is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy more mangoes and a trailer

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chhan

texts.en: Mrs. Chhan S., a widow living in Lvea Sa Kandal village in Kandal Province, is 51 years old and has four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, while the others are studying in local public school. Chhan is a farmer who owns 1.5-hectares of land upon which she cultivates rice to support her family. Because her field is now infertile and far from an irrigation system, she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and fuel and to hire farm laborers to harvest the rice.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and fuel

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Mrs. Sim U., 52, lives with her husband, Mr. Lay Lang, in Kaoh ChamraeU. village in Kandal province. They have four children, one a laborer, one a grocery seller and the other two are farmers. Mr. Lay Lang owns a plot of land to grow vegetables and Mrs. Sim U. sells vegetables in the local market. Since her business is going well she wants to expand it, but she does not have a motorbike for transportation. So Mrs. Sim U. is asking for a loan to buy a motorbike to support her business.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Tong

texts.en: Mr. Tong T., 58, lives in Boeng Kraom village in Kandal province. He and his wife, Mrs. Sarum Pen, are farmers who own a three-hectare plot of land to grow crops to sell to support their family. Their field is ready to plant so Mr. Tong T. is asking for a loan to buy corn and bean seeds to grow. The farm supports seven children, three of whom help their parents in farming, one is a seamstress in a garment factory, and the others are studying in local public school.

loans.use: To buy corn seed and bean seed to grow

loans.name: Mon

texts.en: Mr. Mon H. is 60 years old and lives in Kamnab village in Kandal province. He is a traditional musician who earns some money to support his family. His wife, Mrs. Youn Oem, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. They have two children who are seamstresses in a garment factory. Mr. Mon H. needs transportation to work so is asking for a loan to buy a motorbike.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Sosorl

texts.en: Mr. Sosorl Y., 31, lives in Prachum Angk village in Kandal province. He and his wife, Mrs. Chanty Mou, are tailors and have a two-year old child. They have a problem because their house does not have gate. So, in order to improve the family's living conditions, Mr. Sosorl Y. is asking ask for a loan to construct a gate to protect his house.

loans.use: To construct a gate

loans.name: Mach's Group

texts.en: This group loan consists of five villagers in Tuol Sala village in Kandal province. Mrs. Mach S. is the group leader, selected by all the members who will use the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Mach San is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Phorl Kol, owns a plowing machine. They have two children, one is a clerk and the other is studying in the local public school. Since her husband’s business is going well Mrs. Mach S. wants to expand it. Thus, she is asking for a loan to buy gasoline and parts for the plowing machine.

loans.use: To buy gasoline and parts for her plowing machine

loans.name: Teav's Group

texts.en: In Kamnab village in Kandal province, there are five people who make up this group loan. Mrs. Teav M. is the group leader who was selected by all the members. They will use the loan for different purposes. She and her husband, Mr. Lab Chhan, are farmers who own 1.5 hectares of land to cultivate rice to support their family. Although they try to work hard, they can't earn enough income. For this reason, they want to start a new business but they don't have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Teav M. decided to ask for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. She is a mother of four children. Two of the children are seamstresses in a garment factory, one is enrolled in a local public school, and the other is five years old.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en: Conchita M. is a 73-year-old woman who enjoys performing her role managing her own small “sari-sari” (variety) store. Three of her five children have their own families now while two are her dependents. To be able to sustain their primary needs, Conchita tries to spend her profits wisely and maintain her business. However, due to unstable family cash flow, she can’t avoid using a portion of her business capital for her needs as well as those of her two children. Therefore, she is requesting a much larger loan from ASHI to sustain the business. Conchita’s store is not just helping her family with their daily needs; it also brings convenience to the community. Through the grocery items she sells and other foodstuff, no one has to leave the village and pay for transportation just to buy basic things they need every day. She wishes that someday she will have enough financial capital to stabilize her store and her profit.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia U. has been a member of ASHI for five years now. Since the time of her membership, she and her family have enjoyed the opportunity of getting a loan and financing the maintenance of her own small business, which is buying and selling vegetables. Though Lucia had a hard time sustaining the business because of her small profit and revenue, she remained determined and hopeful that someday her business would grow and give her a sound profit to support the needs of her family, especially her only child who is eight years old. Through a loan she is requesting now, her envisioned business growth will be achieved. Lucia really wants to have savings for the future of her only child and to improve their standard of living. She also wants to be able to augment her husband’s small income. He is a hired laborer.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of vegetables to sell

loans.name: Delia

texts.en: Delia B. is a 49-year-old career woman. She enjoys her life playing several roles in the family and in her society. Despite poverty and the many challenges she faces everyday to make her family happy and to maintain a harmonious relationship at home, Delia remains strong and determined to improve her financial status by growing her small and newly established food vending business. With profits from this business, she hopes to achieve her dream of graduating her five children (whose ages range from seven to 17 years old) and supporting the needs of her eldest child who is disabled. Delia’s loving husband supports her endeavor and decision to request a loan through ASHI. He believes that Delia’s skills and determination to manage a business will enable her to succeed in her chosen career. Having the opportunity of having a large amount of capital will make her business stable as well as her profit because she will have the capacity to increase the quantity of food she cooks and sells to people in their village.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of ingredients for her food production

loans.name: Raisa

texts.en:
Raisa is married with no children. She owns a retail business that sells construction materials. It is a family business where she works with her husband. They started this business six years ago. 

The demand for construction materials has been high. However,  there has been a number of challenging business situations: licensing, competition, clients buying and not paying for the materials. Raisa did not give up. Together with her husband, Raisa was able to overcome difficulties and continue in business. She is very creative and always happy.

Raisa would like to borrow 17,000 UAH to purchase more inventories. She hopes to satisfy the high demand and increase her sales.

loans.use: To purchase more stock

loans.name: Lorina

texts.en: At her young age (33 years old), Lorina G. has become a successful businesswoman. She started her business using the loan she received from ASHI when she became a member in the year 2002. This was just small then but because of so many trials due to poverty, Lorina strived hard to make it grow and expand. Her vision of giving her three children a better future using the proceeds of her business enhanced her eagerness to explore the potentials of her business. Her husband has been so supportive to all her ventures. Looking back at Lorina’s business, now it has a lot of accomplishments. Before, her franchised fried chicken rolling store operated only in one municipality and was transported by bicycle. Now it operates in four neighboring municipalities and is transported by motorcycle. Lorina feels happy with her business achievement. However, it is not yet stable enough for her to feel financially secure. Without her a loan, her business can never grow, especially when time comes when her three children (whose ages are from eight to 13 years) are ready to go to college. Therefore, Lorina is requesting another loan in a larger amount to put up another business, which is a tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar) for transportation. She hopes that by having several businesses, she will have more income, have more savings for the future of her children, and will be able to help her other relatives by employing them to work with her in her businesses.

loans.use: To buy another cart for her business and a sidecar for her tricycle

loans.name: Buloba Development Of  Lugazi Group

texts.en: She is a divorced mother of 8 who herds cattle, pigs and poultry. With profits coming from the sell of some of her domestic animals, 56 year old N. Donata has fully provided for all her children’s education. She began her business venture 6 years ago in Buloba, Lugazi. She has faced many challenges particularly during the dry season where animal feeds are hard to come by. The thoroughbred domestic animals she has been rearing and selling have gotten her a strong inclination among her clients. In a week she says she makes 35,000 shillings. With this loan she wants to enlarge her business by buying more pigs, more chicken and cattle.

loans.use: to purchase  more poultry,pigs, and cattle

loans.name: Im's Group

texts.en: Four people who live in Tuol Krasang village in the Kandal province make up this group loan. Mrs. Im P. is the group leader selected by all the members, who will use the loan for different purposes. She is lotus seller in the local village and her husband, Mr. Thuy Moeng, is a tailor who can earn a small income to support his family's living expenses. Now she has a problem because her husband’s motorbike is broken, but she does not have money. Thus, Mrs. Im P. decided to ask for a loan to fix the motorbike. She is a mother of three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To fix the motorbike

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina A. started her vegetable buying and selling business in 2005.  That same year she joined ASHI in order to receive a loan to finance the growth of her business.  For a number of consecutive years she has received loans from Kiva partner ASHI and she is again requesting a loan in order to be able to increase the volume and turnover of her sales. She works hard and invests emotionally and financially in her business in order to make it successful. Despite the failures and challenges she has encountered, she has never thought of giving up her dreams and has become strong instead in order to continue her fight against poverty. Through the support of her loving husband who died several years ago, her business has grown and she now has larger profits which she uses to support her two children, aged 14 and 19 years old. 

Catalina tries to save some money out of her profits because she plans to purchase a motorcycle for a transportation business which will be managed by her eldest son who did not want to pursue his education in college. He will then have his own source of income and will not just depend on her. Along with that aspiration, she also wants to support the education of her youngest child until she graduates from college and has her own career.

loans.use: To purchase bulk volumes of vegetables.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine D. J. is a 43 year-old unmarried woman who supports her 65 year-old mother, 27 year-old brother and two nephews who are high school students. Financially, her small variety store business is the main source of income for her family. Her customers are people in their village and the store is located in front of their house. 

Josephine really wants to grow this business and also start another business of buying and selling ready to wear clothes. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to be used in her business. With the loan, she will increase her store inventory and better satisfy her customer demands. She hopes to have increased profits which will also support her dream of renovating the family home house in order to have a more comfortable shelter.

loans.use: To purchase various goods and grocery items.

loans.name: Mrs. Phat Ou Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twelve people, who live in Preaek Doung village in Kandal province, make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Phat O. has been selected by all the members as the the village bank president. All the individuals will use their portion of the loan for different purpose. 

Mrs. Phat O. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to grow crops which she sells to support the family income.  In her field, she has a problem because the soil is infertile. Therefore, in order to produce a more productive croup, Mrs. Phat O. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer. She is a widow with eight children, two of whom are body guards, one is a tailor in a local village, the other is a sugar cane and soy mill seller, and the others are attending local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mrs. Pov N. is a villager in Krang Roluos village in Kandal province. She was born in 1950.  She and her husband, Mr. Soeurn Sok, are farmers who own 3-hectares of land to cultivate rice which they sell to support the family.  They try to work hard but still earn insufficient income. Therefore, Mrs. Pov N. is asking for a loan to buy a cow for breeding. 

Mrs. Pov N. is the mother of four children.  Two children are seamstresses in a garment factory, another is a dentist and another is studying in local public school. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Khorn

texts.en: Mrs. Khorn K. lives in Ta Daol Bei village in Kandal province and she is 56 years-old. She owns a general store in the local village. Although she tries to work hard, she earns insufficient income. She decided to start a new business but she did not have enough money to begin. Therefore, Mrs. Khorn K. is asking for a loan to buy ten pigs for breeding. She is a widow with four children, two are seamstresses in a garment factory and the other two attend the local public school.

loans.use: To buy ten pigs for breeding.

loans.name: Francisca  Wangari

texts.en: Francisca, aged 58, is married and lives in the Kahawa Sukari area, a Nairobi suburb. It is an area of mixed businesses with a high population, most of whom are low-income earners. Francisca operates a retail shop and rents houses. She has done this for the last ten years. With this loan, she plans to buy materials like paints and cement so as to finish the rental houses. Her customers are mainly working-class people along the busy Thika Road area and Kahawa Sukari suburb. She has never borrowed from other financial institutions. In the future, she hopes to develop a supermarket in addition to building more rental houses.

loans.use: to finish construction work on rental houses.

loans.name: Moreta

texts.en: Moreta M. is one of the oldest members of the original ASHI center founded in 1996. During that time and despite a lot of challenges she remained strong and supportive of all ASHI programs and activities. She has enjoyed the company of other borrowers and has learned a lot through  the center's weekly meetings. She has enhanced her skills in managing and growing a fishing and fish-selling business because most of them are in the same kind of business. Fishing and selling fish in partnership with her husband is Moreta’s main source of income. She wants to grow her business further until it is stable and can improve her family's standard of living. She is requesting a larger loan through ASHI to buy a motor boat to be managed by her son and husband. That will increase the amount of fish they can catch and sell, increasing her profits. Despite being poor, Moreta believes that, through the loans she can access, someday she will have stable income and a sound life along with her family.

loans.use: To purchase a motor fishing boat.

loans.name: Pha

texts.en: Mrs. Pha K. is a villager in Chrak Chi Koam village in Takeo province. She breeds pigs and on the side makes white wine. Since her business is going well she wants to expand it, but she does not have enough money so is asking for a loan to buy more pigs, pig food, and vaccinations. Her husband, Mr. Khang Yorn, is a teacher in the local school and also farms his three-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice to support his family. They have two children, one a teacher, and the other in school.

loans.use: To buy more pigs, pig food, and vaccinations

loans.name: Kavumbi

texts.en: Kavumbi is married to a mason and has four girls and one boy. Only two of her children were able to attend school. Kavumbi sells cassavas, coconuts, and brooms. She has been in this business for 10 years and has no other sources of income. She sells her products wholesale door to door. Her customers are retailers and food vendors. Her greatest challenge is that her customers don't always make their payments. She aspires to be a dairy farmer and with the ksh. 30,000, loan she wants to purchase a dairy cow and pay for brooms and coconuts in advance. Kavumbi owns her home but does not have electricity or running water. Her greatest monthly expense is food. She hopes to lift her living standard and educate her children.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow, coconuts, brooms

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en: Teodora Orelloso lives in San Jose, province of Antique with her four children and loving husband. Although poor they enjoy a harmonious relationship within the family. Their main source of income comes from the buy and sell “ukay- ukay” business Teodora and her husband manage. “Ukay-ukay” is a popular source of clothes and other items such as bags, and shoes. These are used items imported from other countries that can be bought at a cheaper price yet the quality is excellent. With the loan she requests, Teodora hopes to purchase goods in large volume and with more variety to display and sell in the town’s public market. She hopes to support the education of her children until they graduate from college.

loans.use: To purchase used clothes and garments in volume.

loans.name: Selina

texts.en:
Selina is a widow with five boys and three girls. Five of her children attend school. Selina sells charcoal and wants to purchase 10 sacks of charcoal with the Ksh.15,000 loan. She has been in this business for five years and was previously selling fish. Her other source of income is from selling vegetables door-to-door and from rental housing. Her customers are mainly her neighbors. 

The main challenge to her business is that there are so many people who sell charcoal that there is a lot of competition. Selina owns her home but has no piped water or electricity. Her greatest expenses are food and school fees. She hopes that in two or three years she will have renovated her rental house and that she will lead a happy life.

loans.use: 10 sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Kokadiyereye Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Kokadiyèrèyé, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 36 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Gonido sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de condiments alimentaires et  de céréales tels Rokia D..
Ces femmes du groupe Kokadiyèrèyé sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire à l’instar de Rokia D. qui compte utiliser le sien pour acheter  des sacs de céréales.
Elle s’approvisionne le plus généralement à Fana et environs. Elle effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Tingolé et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Rokia compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Kokadiyèrèyé group are all married and are, on average, 36 years old, have five children and live in traditional extended families in Gonido, in the Fana prefecture, in the region of Koulikoro (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know each other through family ties and are engaged in the sale of food condiments and cereals, as does Rokia D.. These women of the Kokadiyèrèyé group are on their fourth joint loan following the example of Rokia D., who plans to use her loan to buy sacks of cereals. She generally gets her supplies in and around Fana. She makes her sales from home, at the market in Tingolé, and at neighboring markets, at retail, in cash and on credit, to a clientele of men and women. Rokia plans to clear a monthly profit of 20.000 FCFA which will be used for the family’s daily expenses, and the rest will be reinvested in her business.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cereals

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a widowed woman with two girls. She has been selling coconuts for the past 15 years and wants to use the Ksh. 20,000 loan to purchase 50 palm trees whose coconuts she can then sell. Her other source of income is from palm wine. She sells wholesale at the market and her customers are mainly food vendors. 

Her greatest challenge is that some clients don't pay their debt. Her goal is to export her coconuts and to open a water kiosk someday. She owns her home but has no piped water or electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is food and she started working with Yehu because she needed a loan to educate her daughters.

loans.use: 50 palm trees

loans.name: Tiessiri Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Tièssiri, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 33 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Gonido sous préfecture de Fana, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de condiments alimentaires, de charbon de bois à l’image de Tata Traoré et de  céréales.
Ces femmes du groupe Tièssiri sont à leur quatrième prêt solidaire et Tata Traoré compte utiliser le sien pour acheter, des chargements de charrettes en sacs de charbon de bois. 
Elle approvisionne généralement  à Fana auprès des producteurs et effectue  sa vente sur place, au marché de Tingolé et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 7.500FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Tièssiri group are all married and are, on average, 33 years old, have four children and live in traditional extended families in Gonido, in the Fana prefecture, in the region of Koulikoro (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know each other through family ties and are engaged in the sale of food condiments, charcoal--like Tata Traoré--and cereals. These women of the Tièssiri group are on their fourth joint loan and Tata Traoré plans to use hers to buy cartloads of sacks of charcoal. She generally gets her supplies from producers in Fana and makes her sales from home, at the market in Tingolé and in neighboring markets, at retail, in cash and on credit, to a clientele of men and women. She plans to clear a monthly profit of 7,500 FCFA which will be used to meet the daily expenses of the family and the rest will be invested in her business.

Translated from French by Shannon Arnold, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy charcoal

loans.name: Assitan

texts.fr:
Madame Assitan Sidibé est âgée de 26 ans, mariée et mère d’une fille. Elle vit avec son mari et son enfant  dans une famille traditionnelle dans le quartier Hamdallaye de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fait l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle commença très tôt à mener des activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage, elle évolue seule en menant le même genre de commerce que sa mère, depuis maintenant 8 ans et jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. Elle est bien connue dans le marché château et sa force de vente est due à la qualité de ses articles.
 Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour faire face à la demande clientèle, elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son 1er prêt individuel.
Elle compte utiliser  ce prêt pour acheter, 20 kg de poivre, 10kg de fiéfié et 5kg de l’ail, des paniers de tomates fraîches, des paquets de cube maggi et un sac de sel de cuisine à Bamako auprès des grossistes.  
Madame Assitan Sidibé vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 75 000 FCFA, qui lui permettra de  diversifier ses activités en faisant l’embouche ovine et de constituer des trousseaux de mariage pour sa fille. 
Son ambition est de construire une maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Assitan Sidibé is 26 years old, married and has a daughter. She lives with her husband and child in a traditional family in the Hamdallaye district of the town of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). For social reasons she did not go to school and learnt at an early age from her mother, who sold condiments, how to manage an income generating activity. After several years' apprenticeship, she has for the past eight years been developing by herself the same kind of business as her mother, and she enjoys a large customer base and a certain notoriety. She is well known at the Castle market and the strength of her sales is due to the quality of her products. With a view to increasing her business in order to meet customer demand, she has turned to the micro-finance institution, Soro Yiriwso, from which she has been granted her first loan. She is planning on using this loan to buy 20kg of pepper, 10kg of "fiéfié" and 5kg of garlic, baskets of fresh tomatoes, packets of Maggi stock cubes and a bag of kitchen salt, from wholesalers in Bamako. Mrs. Assitan Sidibé sells on cash and for credit to a customer base made up of men and women. She is hoping to make a monthly profit of 75,000FCFA which will allow her to diversify her activities, by carrying out sheep fattening and making up wedding trousseaux for her daughter. Her ambition is to build a house to live in.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of condiments

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is a married woman with no children. She rents houses and would like to repair her property and install piped water with the Ksh. 20,000 loan.  Her other source of income is from selling fresh water from a kiosk to neighbors. The greatest challenge to her business is that most of the time there is no water. Her greatest monthly expenses are water, electricity, and supporting her parents. Janet aspires to be a big water supplier with tanks and a water pump someday and to be profitable.

loans.use: Repairing property and installing piped water

loans.name: Koumba

texts.fr:
Madame   Koumba C. est âgée de 46 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle vit avec ses enfants et son mari  dans quartier Pelengana sud de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Aide soignante de formation, en plus de ce métier elle fait le commerce d’articles divers avec l’achat vente, de temps à autres, de téléviseurs, de radios, de magnétoscopes, de riz et du lait en poudre (en sachets et en sacs)  depuis maintenant 15 ans  
Elle bénéfice d’une fidèle  clientèle qui est constituée du corps médical et d’autres fonctionnaires de la place.
 Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour faire face à la demande clientèle, elle a  fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 5 ans, après 3 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts  individuels tous  remboursés correctement. 
Elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 10 sacs de lait en poudre et quelques cartons de sachets de lait en poudre  à Tombouctou.  
Madame  Koumba C. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 60.000 FCFA, qui lui permettra de prendre en charge les dépense familiales et de terminer sa maison en construction.
texts.en:
Mrs. Koumba C. is 46 years old, married and the mother of three chilrden. She lives with husband and children in the South Pelengana district of Ségou, in the fourth administrative region of Mali. She is a nursing aide by profession, but in addition she occasionally trades in various items, such TV sets, radios, videotape players, rice and powdered milk (in packets and in bags). She has been doing this for 15 years now. She has a loyal customer base, composed from healthcare workers and other local employees. In order to increase her business capital and better meet customer demand, she has turned for help to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. She has been dealing with Soro Yiriwaso for five years, and had three joint loans and three individual loans, all properly reimbursed. This would be her fourth individual loan, and she plans to use it for purchasing ten bags of powdered milk and several cartons of packets of powdered milk in Tombouctou. Mrs. Koumba C. sells for cash and in credit to a customer base composed of both men and women. She plans to achieve a monthly income of 60,000 West African Francs, which will allow her to manage the family budget and to finish the construction of her home.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing of powdered milk (for resale)

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia is a married pregnant woman with six children between the ages of 13 and 2 years old. Her children all attend school except for the youngest. She also cares for two additional family members as their father (her brother-in-law) has died. Her husband is a carpenter and she has a shop where she has been selling detergent, eggs, flour, cooking fat, and sugar for the past year. 

With the Ksh. 20,000 loan she wants to purchase more items for her shop such as cooking oil, sugar, rice, beans, and detergent. She also wants to repair her business premises. Her greatest challenge is that some people buy on credit but never pay her. She wanted to join Yehu because she saw other women benefit. She owns her home but does not have water or electricity. Her greatest monthly expenses are water, food, and school fees. Rukia hopes to educate her children so that in the future they can help her.

loans.use: More items for her shop such as cooking oil, sugar, rice, beans, and detergent and to repair her shop

loans.name: Ishongororo Twekundire Group

texts.en:
Hard working R. Aidah, aged 48 years, started her retail shop business ten years ago. Being strategically located in Kakinga trading centre, Ishongororo, she gets many customers, earning her a profit of 60,000 Ugandan shillings monthly. Aidah’s main drawback is having a small amount of stock that cannot match the demand from her customers.

With this loan Aidah hopes to buy more stock for her business. This will help her expand her market and also earn more sales revenue to cater for the requirements of her three children, who are still undergoing school, and also be able to progress economically.

Aidah belongs to a group of twelve members who are on their 9th loan. They hold each other accountable and insure each other in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To buy more stock for her business

loans.name: Mwanahamis

texts.en:
Mwanahamis is a married woman with four children under the age of 11. Her oldest child is attending school. She additionally takes care of her parents. She purchases vegetables from the market and sells them at home to neighbors. With the Ksh. 15,000 loan, she hopes to improve her house, build a shop, and buy more vegetables, soap, and flour to sell. 

Her greatest challenge is that food goes bad when there are no customers and that sometimes people buy on credit but don't pay. She owns her home but does not have water or electricity. She cites food, water and paraffin as her greatest monthly expenses. She joined Yehu so that she could improve her life.

loans.use: Build a shop and buy more vegetables, soap and flour to sell

loans.name: Kart-E- Chahar Group

texts.en:
Morsal, daughter of M. R., is 24 years old and is the group leader of Kart-e-Chahar Group.  She lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and she has a tailoring business. She has been involved in this business for more than 5 years. When she started this business for the first time, she had a small business and she was very weak in running the business, but when she got an individual loan, she really improved a lot in her business and still she is furthering her business, attracting a good number of customers, making a good income for her family, and repaying the loan without any difficulty and on time. 

She is happy with this loan. She would like to thank both Kiva and AFS (Ariana Financial Serves Joint Stock Company) and all lenders around the world who help workers and people who would like to expand their businesses. Finally, she wants to say that this process is a successful one in Afghanistan.

loans.use: buy a new muchine for her tailoring

loans.name: Oyun-Erdene

texts.en:
Oyun-Erdene is 32 years old and lives with her two daughters, father, sister and sibling in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent. Oyun-Erdene operates a tailoring business with her sister in their town. Her sister is an experienced seamstress who has worked in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, for many years, and has trained Oyun-Erdene in tailoring. 

Oyun-Erdene started the tailoring business with her sister in 2008, and they have been successfully operating their business since then. They have been planning to rent a workshop beginning in April 2010. Oyun-Erdene is a very hard-working person who has a great business mind. She is requesting a 1,200,000 tugrug loan to increase her working capital and to purchase two electric sewing machines and a lock stitch machine for her business.

loans.use: To purchase electric sewing machines

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is a married woman whose husband has part-time jobs. They have three children, 22, 20 and 16 years old, who attend school. Anna makes liquid and solid soap. With the Ksh. 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase more chemicals necessary to make soaps and containers in which to mix them. She has been in this business for over 20 years and previously sold groceries in the market. 

Anna sells soap wholesale, door-to-door, and has clients such as hotels and restaurants. She has no other sources of income. She decided to work with Yehu because group members are committed and Yehu gives out loans on time.  She owns her house, which has electricity but no water. She hopes to purchase a plot for a permanent home. Anna describes herself as hard-working, dependent on herself, and committed to her business.

loans.use: Container and chemicals to make soap

loans.name: Battulga

texts.en:
Battulga lives with his family in Ulaanbaatar, the largest and the capital city of Mongolia. Battulga operates a carpentry business. He has been operating his business since 2003, and produces a variety of wooden furniture as well as working as a construction contractor. In April 2009, Battulga received 45 days of carpentry training from GTZ (German Technical Cooperation) in order to improve his skills. 

Battulga operated his business from his home until 2009, but has been renting a workshop in the 10th micro district in Mongolia. He has been expanding his business and recently ordered Chinese equipment for manufacturing wooden windows. Battulga plans to begin manufacturing vacuum windows in the near future. He is a very industrious person and is focused on the future. He says, “I would like to successfully reach my goal of becoming a reliable client of the bank in order to grow my business into a stable operation with financial support.” He is requesting a 1,250,000 tugrug loan to increase his working capital and to purchase more timber and other necessary equipment  for his business.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Bi Bi Nesa Group

texts.en:
Farzana, daughter of Z., is married and is an educated woman and the leader of Bi bi Nesa group. She has a needlework business. She has been involved in this business for more than five years. She got her first-cycle loan and completed her stock and still she is furthering her business. She is a good client. When a Kiva Fellow came to Afghanistan and saw this business, she was really happy. Farzana wants to continue her partnership with both Kiva and Ariana. 

Farzana is happy with this loan process. When she found AFS and started her partnership and until now, during this time she has never been faced with any difficulties, therefore, she would like to receive another loan to progress more.

Finally, she wants to thank lenders around the world who help those who really want to expand their businesses.

loans.use: to complete her stock

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a divorced woman with two children, who are 21 and 20 years old. Her older daughter is married and her younger daughter attends school. With the Ksh. 15,000 loan, she wants to purchase goats so that she can to close down her restaurant and focus on selling goats. She has had a restaurant for three years and sells chapati, beans, kale and other foods. 

Her greatest challenge to her business is that she is situated in a place where customers are school children so during the holidays she doesn't have many customers. She lives in her family house and has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are for food and water. Alice joined Yehu because she was noticing improvements in the lives of the women in her community who are clients of Yehu.

loans.use: Goats

loans.name: Oyun-Erdene

texts.en:
Oyun-Erdene is 35 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', the traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Oyun-Erdene operates a meat-trading business in her town. She started her business in 2000 with a working capital of (~ 650 USD). After years of successful operations she has managed to increase her working capital to more than 4,500,000 tugrugs (~  3251 USD). 

Oyun-Erdene purchases meat at wholesale prices in the 'soums' of Bulgan and Tsenher, and resells it for a profit. Over the years, she has gained much experience and built up a loyal customer base. Oyun-Erdene is an honest person who has good communication skills. She is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more meat for her business.

loans.use: To purchase meat

loans.name: Neema

texts.en: Neema Y. is an entrepreneur and a married woman. She runs a business as a food vendor at Yombo Makangarawe in Dar es Salaam. She prepares and sells varieties of both cooked and fried food to customers. She purchases the business goods from the food shops and food market center. She managed to open another business selling traditional clothes for income generation. Also she employs two workers who help her in running the business. She is requesting a loan of T.shs 1,000,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Amarsaihan

texts.en:
Amarsaihan is 31 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent. Her two sons, ages 5 and 2, have not reached school age yet.  Amarsaihan operates a used products business in her town. She started her business in 1999 with working capital of 30,000 tugrugs (~  21 USD), but after a lot of hard work and determination, her working capital is now 600,000 tugrugs. 

Over the years, she has gained a great deal of experience and built a loyal customer base. She purchases inventory 1-2 times a month. With her business profits, she has purchased some livestock in the countryside. Amarsaihan is an honest person who has been working hard to create a bright future for her family. She is requesting a 400,000 tugrugs loan to purchase more inventory for her business.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Ashura

texts.en: Ashura I. is a small businesswoman and married. She runs a business selling traditional clothes ( Vitenge and Khanga ) at Yombo Buza  ward in Dar es Salaam.She purchases the business goods direct from the wholesale shops at Mnazi Mmoja traditional-clothes shopping center. She opened another business selling powdered soap to customers. She purchases it wholesale and packages it in retail form. She manages to meet her family's daily needs from the business income and business capitalization. She needs a loan of T.shs 1,000,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Shamila Shakila Group

texts.en:
Shamila is the daughter of H.. She is 42 years old and the leader of Shamila Shakila group. She is married with six children and lives in District 7 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is uneducated. Her youngest son has a retail food shop and he is the responsible one for all his family members. 

Shamila wants to take out a loan for her son. Her family has an economical problem at home. Her son needs money. His mother (Shamila) is taking a loan from AFS for her son to buy more materials for the shop such as rice, baskets and milk to make a good life for his whole family. He is the only one to help his family and he wants to find close relationships with people to find more clients to make a better life for his family.

loans.use: buy more groceries for his shop

loans.name: Dulamsuren

texts.en:
Dulamsuren is 51 years old and lives with her husband and three children in an apartment in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. Her husband cannot work due to suffering from a brain hemorrhage and receives a pension from the government. Her family has been living together in their current home for 10 years. 

Dulamsuren operates a grocery store, and her business is her family's only source of income. She has been operating her business since 2005, and has a loyal customer base. Dulamsuren is an open-minded person who is working hard to improve her family's standard of living. She has been planning to support her oldest son in creating a household of his own. 

Dulamsuren is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more food products for her grocery store. Her profits tend to remain high as long as she maintains a wide product selection.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Bulgamaa

texts.en:
Bulgamaa is 42 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a 'ger', the Mongolian nomadic tent. Bulgamaa operates a dairy product trading business in her town. She sells a variety of diary products, including milk, curds and yogurt, at the local Hasu trading center. 

Bulgamaa started her business in 1991 with working capital of 50,000 tugrugs (~  36 USD), and she has steadily expanded her business since that time. Today her working capital has grown to 550,000 tugrugs (~  400 USD). She has gained valuable experience as a businesswoman and has a loyal customer base. Her husband supports her business and both of them are very hard-working people. 

Bulgamaa makes an effort to communicate effectively with others. She is requesting a 600,000 tugrug loan to purchase more dairy products for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more dairy products

loans.name: Tumurhuyag

texts.en:
Tumurhuyag is 53 years old and lives with his wife and seven children in Hovd province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife, Altanchimeg, sells iron products at a local market. During the day, Tumurhuyag operates an electrical products and food retailing business in his town. He has been operating his business since 2000, and has steadily expanded it.

He purchases products every two months in Taikeshken, a Chinese border city, and resells them from a shipping container in his own province. Tumurhuyag has gained a great deal of experience in the previous ten years, and his sales are very good. Tumurhuyag is an industrious person who has a great business mind. He is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug (~ 2167 USD) loan to purchase more inventory for his business.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Nasir Wafa Group

texts.en:
Nasir Ahmad is the son of M. S. and the leader of Nasir Wafa group. He is married with 4 children and lives with his own family. He has a car wash shop and has been involved in this business for a long time. He got the first-cycle loan, used it for his business and has been advancing his business. Now he plans to enlarge his business and wants to take out his second-cycle loan.

Therefore, he has requested a loan to enlarge his shop, change its design, and complete his stock . He would love to be a good business dealer in the future.

loans.use: He wants to enlarge his shop

loans.name: Yanjintseveg

texts.en:
Yanjintseveg is 43 years old and lives with his wife and child in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. His child attends a university. His wife is an x-ray technician at a general hospital, and during her spare time she helps with Yanjintseveg's business.

Yanjintseveg receives a disability payment from the government. However, his physical disability is not a significant impediment, and he forges ahead to ensure a good future with his wife. Yanjintseveg was an electrician with a local energy center between 2003 and 2008. Since 2008 he has operated a movie rental business from a shipping container at a local market.

He plans to expand his business in the future. Yanjintseveg is a very hardworking person and is focused on the future. He says, “I would like to grow my business in the future, and improve my family's quality of life.” He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~ 722 USD) loan to increase his working capital for his business.

loans.use: To increase his working capital

loans.name: Maulid

texts.en:
Maulid J. is a married small businessman with three school-age children. He runs a business selling phone accessories at his shop at Mbagala ward in Dar es Salaam. He purchases the business goods from the wholesale phone accessories shops at Kariakoo business shopping center.

He meets his family's daily needs from the business income, including paying school fees. He is requesting a loan of T.shs 1,000,000 to boost the business with more inventory.

loans.use: To boost his business with more inventory

loans.name: Purevsuren

texts.en:
Purevsuren is 43 years old and lives with her husband and two children in the Songinohairhan district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. They have been living together in their current home for 10 years.

Purevsuren operates a carpentry business with her husband. They manufacture wooden parts and furniture, such as doors and frames for gers. They started their business in 2003, and have steadily expanded since then. Purevsuren's brother-in-law sells their products at his shipping container at a local market.

Purevsuren is a very hardworking person and has many plans for the future. She says, “I would like to establish a wooden products factory for my oldest son in the future.” She is requesting a 410,000 tugrug (~ 300 USD) loan to increase her working capital and to purchase necessary materials, such as paint, for her business.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Karima Qamar Group

texts.en:
Qamar Gull is 22 years old and the leader of Karima Qamar group. She lives in Kabul Afghanistan and is married with two children. Her husband has a small shop selling fresh fruit and vegetables in Kabul. He needs a small loan for his business because he wants to enlarge his shop and business to better support his family and make a good income.

Therefore, Qamar Gull has requested a loan with which her husband wants to expand and progress his business. He will buy more fresh fruit for his shop to attract more customers and become a good business dealer in the future.

loans.use: Expand business by buying more fresh fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more business materials

loans.name: Boafo Ye Na Group

texts.en:
Akua D. describes herself as truthful, a woman who faces reality. She is 53 years old and is the leader of the 'Boafo Ye Na' borrower group. Akua lives in Bibiani and sells dried fish in the new market in town. She has been running her fish business for 5 years. Akua is excited to be taking out this loan, which she will use to purchase one large basket of dried fish. Previously, this loan amount would have enabled her to purchase two medium baskets of dried fish, but the market pricing is increasing and fish is becoming more expensive in her community.
