Akua also runs an herbal medicine business. She goes to the forest, gathers herbs and plants, and prepares the medicines herself. She wants to use the extra profits she anticipates as a result of this loan to buy a plot of land and build a small structure from which she can operate her medicine business. She still anticipates selling dried fish as supplemental income in the future. 

Akua is married to a primary school teacher and together they have seven children. Akua aims to sell enough fish and medicine to be able to provide good education for all of her children, hopefully through University level. 

As the leader of the 'Boafo Ye Na' borrower group, Akua ensures that all members attend meetings and submit their repayments. The other women in Akua’s group operate businesses selling various foods.

loans.use: To purchase one large basket of dried fish to sell to customers

loans.name: Barg Sabz Group

texts.en:
M. Haroon is the son of A. J. and the leader of Barg Sabz group. He lives in the 7th district of Kabul, Afghanistan and has a big family with eight members. He runs a mobile phone and credit card shop and he has been involved in this business for more the 15 years. Now he needs a small loan for his business to become strong and to help with his family in a better way.

He requested a loan to enlarge his business. He wants to expand and progress the business, which requires hard work and also buying necessary materials to complete his stock.

So he is very happy about this process of offering small loans in Afghanistan, and wants to especially thank Kiva lenders around the world.

loans.use: He wants to buy necessary materials to expand his shop

loans.name: Sarafina

texts.en:
Sarafina O. O. is a married small businesswoman. She runs a business selling used (second hand) clothes at Karume business market in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the business goods from the wholesale shops at Mnazi Mmoja Street in Dar es Salaam and sells to retail customers.

The business income generated is used to meet her family's daily demand and for business capitalization. She needs a loan of T.shs 500,000 to capitalize the business by buying more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods and capitalize the business

loans.name: Djiguiya  (L’Espoir) Group

texts.fr:
Djiguiya est un regroupement de femmes du quartier Koko de la ville de Koutiala qui se connaissent bien et vivent dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris et enfants. Elles ont en moyenne 38 ans et sont mères d’au moins 4 enfants.
Les femmes du groupe Djiguiya font le commerce d’articles divers : céréales, bois de chauffe, préparation et vente de galettes tels Mariam B., habillements etc.
 Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux ans. 
Mariam B. qui est dans l’alimentaire compte utiliser son prêt pour se procurer  des grains de petit mil, de l’huile et du sucre au  grand marché de Koutiala et du bois de chauffe à la maison auprès des producteurs des villages environnants.
Elle vend les galettes chaque soir devant sa porte en face du goudron et de l’école de la mission catholique. Elle est très sollicitée car sait bien  faire les galettes qui sont très prisées.
Tandis que les autres membres du groupe Djiguiya comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 80 000 FCFA chacune au  cours de ce cycle, Mariam B., compte réaliser 110 000 FCFA.  
En plus du remboursement des prêts, elles utiliseront une partie du revenu  pour faire face aux dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Elles souhaitent  renforcer le partenariat avec  Soro Yiriwaso pour ne plus avoir de rupture de stocks.
texts.en:
Djiguiya [“hope”] is the name of a group of women from the Koko district in the town of Koutiala. They know each other well and all live in large traditional famlies with their husbands and children. They are 38 years of age on the average, and each woman has at least four children. The women of the Djiguiya group trade in various articles: cereals, heating wood, preparation and sale of pancakes (such as the ones Mariam B. bakes), clothing etc. In order to enlarge the scope of their activities, two years ago they have decided to take advantage of the loan programs of Soro Yiriwaso. Mariam B., who is in food sales, plans to use her loan in order to purchase millet grain, oil and sugar at the big market of Kouiala and heating wood from the vendors of nearby towns. Je sells her pancakes each evening in front of her front door, on the pavement by the Catholic mission school. There is a lot of customer demand as she is good at baking pancakes and they are very popular. While other members of the Djiguiya group plan to obtain a monthly income of 80,000 West African Francs each, Mariam B. plans to achieve an income of 110,000 West African francs. In addition to repaying the loan, they will use the income to help meet the family expenses. They seek collaboration with Soro Yiriwaso in order to avoid running out of stock on their goods.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing millet grain and other ingredients for the preparation of pancakes

loans.name: Yeredon (Se Connaître) Group

texts.fr:
Yeredon est un regroupement de femmes, toutes mariées, ayant  en moyenne 34 ans, 3 enfants et vivant dans de grandes familles traditionnelles avec leurs maris et enfants dans la quartier Madina Koura de la ville de Koutiala (troisième région de la république du Mali). 
Le groupe Yeredon fait essentiellement l’achat et la vente des chaussures, des habits, des fruits et légumes etc. 
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres du groupe Yeredon ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso il y a trois ans. Elles sont à leur  cinquième prêt de groupe et tous les prêts précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Quant à l’utilisation du prêt, Awa Koné, qui excelle dans l’habillement compte se procurer  de ses marchandises constituées de pagnes wax, d’habits pour femmes et enfants et des draps de lits  à Bobo Dioulaso (Burkina Faso). Elle vend ses articles,  au grand marché de Koutiala, de façon ambulante dans les entreprises et  de porte en porte dans les quartiers, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle diverse et variée. 
Les autres membres du groupe Yeredon espèrent réaliser un bénéfice de 170 000 FCFA chacune au  cours de ce cycle et quant à Awa Koné, elle envisage  avoir  au cours du cycle un bénéfice de 205 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt et les  dépenses courantes de la famille. 
Awa Koné ambitionne tout comme celles qui sont dans l’habillement  ouvrir une boutique de vêtements à Koutiala.
texts.en:
Yeredon is a group of married women who average age 34. They live in large, traditional families with their husbands and children in the Madina Koura quarter of Koutiala city (third administrative region of Mali). The Yeredon group buys and sells shoes, clothing, fruits, vegetable, etc. To increase the size of their business, the members of the Yeredon group decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso credit program three years ago. They are on their fifth group loan; all of their previous loans have been repaid in full. With this loan, Awa Koné - whose excels selling clothing - counts on buying merchandise like waxed fabric, female and children's clothing, and bed sheets in Bobo Dioulaso (in Burkina Faso). She sells this merchandise at the grand market of Koutiala, traveling to businesses, and door-to-door in surrounding quarters. Her sales are made in cash and credit to a diverse clientele. The other members of the Yeredon group hope to make a profit of 170,000 FCFA each. With Awa Koné, they envision making an additional profit of 205,000 FCFA which will be used to repay the loan and pay for household expenses. Awa Koné, like many who trade clothes, aspires to one day open a clothing store in Koutiala

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothing

loans.name: Ferdinand

texts.en:
Ferdinand Otoole S. is forty-four years old, married and has three children. His business is located at Magongo Estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the white Indian Ocean beaches. He has been selling such items as rice, flour, oil, detergents, soft drinks and other items for the last ten years to the local people.

He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is there are so many people doing the same kind of business in the area and so customers have many choices. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 80,000 to buy more general items to expand his business. He hopes to be a wholesaler in future. He is a very hard-working man.

loans.use: buy general items to expend retail business

loans.name: Zalmai Tabesh Group

texts.en: Zalmai, the son of N. M. and a married father of four children, is the 31-year-old leader of Zalmai Tabesh Group.  He lives in Kabul Afghanistan where he has a taxi that he wants to buy new tires and some tools for. He is therefore requesting a loan from AFS (Ariana Financial Services Joint Stock Company), happy that there is a process that can solve entrepreneurs’ problems.

loans.use: To buy new tires and tools for his taxi

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth is a 50-year-old married lady. She runs a tailoring shop, where she styles men's and women's clothes, and also sells utensils to earn a living. She has been in the business for 10 years and has two employees. She also practices farming on her farm to earn extra income.  

She belongs to a group called Ujamaa in Faulu Kenya, a Kiva partner. The group members save their money and guarantee each other's loans. She hopes to open outlets and improve her living standards in the future. She is unable to meet her many customers' demands and therefore, she has requested a loan of 60,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya to add stock of fabric and utensils.

loans.use: To buy more fabric and utensils for sale

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema I. is a small-scale businesswoman. She runs a grocery business in the Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam. She sells a variety of goods, including soft drinks and beer. She purchases the goods from suppliers and local shops. She plans to expand the business as she generates more customers. She is requesting a loan of 700,000 Tanzanian shillings to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy business goods

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel, who is 32 years old and married, runs a tailoring business to earn a living. In business for six years and with one employee, he makes a range of clothing with a variety of designs per his customers' requests. Daniel is a professional who has a loyal customer base because of his good service.   He saves his money with his group in Faulu Kenya called Emmanuel so as to support the needs of his family.  Daniel has requested a loan of kes 30,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy fabric, and he hopes to expand his business and stabilize his income in the future.

loans.use: To buy fabric

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Chalwe

texts.en: Chalwe C., a married businesswoman, sells both new and second hand clothes at Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam. Purchasing her goods from the wholesale shops in Karume city market and Kariakoo city shopping center, she retails them to her customers. Chalwe has been in the business for four years, supporting both her family and business from her proceeds. She now needs a loan of T.shs 1,000,000 to buy more business goods

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice is 42 years old and married with two children who are in school. She offers cell phone money transfer services to earn a living. In addition  she sells cell phone sim cards and credit cards. She has been in this business for a long time and has five employees. Since joining Faulu Kenya and having access to loans, she has been able to educate her children to high school level. She has requested a loan of kes 80,000 from Faulu Kenya to open another cell phone money transfer shop. She hopes to grow her business and build her family a house in the future.

loans.use: To open a cell phone money transfer services shop.

loans.name: Annie

texts.en: Annie is 30 years old and married with two children. She has run a salon where she offers hair dressing and beauty therapy services for four years.   She uses her income to help her husband (who runs a studio business) with the household expenses. Since she joined Faulu Kenya her business has expanded. She saves her money with her group in Faulu Kenya which guarantees loans to its members. Annie has requested a loan of kes 30,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy hair extensions, braids, and hair chemicals. She dreams of building her family a house in the future since they now live in a rented house.

loans.use: To buy hair extensions, braids and hair chemicals.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Agahikaine Karungyi Parish, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
N. Wilberforce is a 42-year-old married father of eight boisterous schoolchildren. To shoulder his responsibility of providing for them, he has, over the course of the last four years, been operating a retail shop in Kawanijju in Kyenjojo. His business has not been without setbacks since he began.

Wilberforce has had to bear a myriad of challenges, such as the lack of steady income. In a way, however, his business has remained active. This he principally attributes to the good working chord he has struck with his clientele.

In a week, Wilberforce says he makes more than 50,000 Ugandan shillings, a figure he admits will not substantively make his business see the light of day in the near future. He is therefore seeking a loan to lend countenance to his business. With this loan, he says he will be able to buy more garments and other forms of merchandise for his shop.

Wilberforce belongs to a group of nineteen members who support one another in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To buy more stock for his store

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter K. Musika is 35 and married with four children to whom he hopes to give a quality education. His business is located in Changamwe estate in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya well known for its many tourist attractions including the Indian ocean's white beaches. He has been selling such items as traditional baskets, chains, bangles and other things for the last eight years to the local people and the tourists. He says that his business is profitable but seasonal. However he works very hard to keep it going and doing well. Peter will use his loan of Kes 20,000 to buy materials to make the items that he sells and expand his business. He hopes that his business will grow to the point of being able to export his products. He is a very hard-working man.

loans.use: Materials.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a 49-year-old widow woman raising 4 children. Two of her children help her by contributing income from their jobs to manage the heavy expenses of life. 

For the past 15 years, Mariam has worked as a farmer to support her family. She owns a large plot land where she cultivates all types of vegetables and a variety of trees. 

Today, Mariam is requesting $1,200 to purchase fertilizer and seeds to plant summer vegetables in order to augment the harvest and thus her income.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and seeds for summer vegetables

loans.name: Symon

texts.en:
Symon is 28 years old and married with two children in school.  He was previously employed as a public-service vehicle driver before he started his own business.  He saves his money with a Faulu Kenya group called Rehema, which guarantees loans to its members.

To earn a living, Symon buys kerosene from gas stations in large quantities--thereby benefiting from economies of scale--and then sells it to the residents of Dandora in Nairobi.  He has been in this business for three years and has one employee.  He says that his turnover is high because kerosene is mostly used as a cooking fuel in the area.

Symon has requested for a loan of KES 30,000 from Faulu Kenya to purchase a stock of kerosene for resale.

loans.use: To purchase kerosene for resale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Roselyne

texts.en:
Roselyne is 35 years old and married with four children.  Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been saving her money with the Soweto Express group, which guarantees loans to its members.   

To earn a living, Roselyne runs a carpentry workshop; she has been in the business since 2005, and has three employees. She also runs a tailoring business to earn extra income.  

Roselyne has requested for a loan of KES 30,000 from Faulu Kenya to purchase raw materials for her workshop. She hopes to expand her business and improve her standard of living in the future.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for a carpentry workshop

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Gonzalo

texts.es:
Gonzalo es un señor de 35 años, casado con 2 hijos de 2 y 7 años, viven en la zona del Barrio Fabril, inmediaciones de la Av. Blanco Galindo Km 7 en la Zona de Colcapirua, de la Provincia Cercado. Zona considerada agrícola, pues se encuentra en la periferia de la ciudad de Cochabamba.

Gonzalo se trabaja como chofer de un taxi, que hace su recorrido en la zona, su esposa trabaja en una escuela que se encuentra en la comunidad de Pucarita Chica, a tres horas de viaje de su casa, tomando hasta tres movilidades, pero ellos se acomodan a los horarios y necesidades que tienen y están acostumbrados a levantarse muy de madrugada todos los días, sus pequeños hijos se quedan al cuidado de su abuelita mientras ambos esposos trabajan en las mañanas, pues son muy pequeños y el ultimo tuvo problemas de labio leporino, para lo cual por ayudas extranjeras pudieron operarlo, aun así requería de los cuidados y atención de sus padres para su recuperación pues tuvo complicaciones, para lo cual la esposa de Gonzalo tuvo que dejar durante un año su empleo. Ahora que su pequeño hijo se encuentra mejor y ya se ha recuperado ambos esposos están decididos a trabajar mucho para poder recuperarse de la operación de su pequeño hijito.

Gonzalo solicito el crédito para poder compra repuestos a su herramienta de trabajo (taxi) y realizarle un mantenimiento general a la misma. El nos cuenta que uno de sus mayores sueños es algun dia ganar lo suficiente para poder dejar que su esposa deje de trabajar y se dedique 100% a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Gonzalo is a 35 year old man who is married with 2 children, aged 2 and 7. He lives in the Barrio Fabril zone near Blanco Galindo Avenue at Km. 7 in the Colcapirua Zone of Cercado Province. This zone is considered agricultural, since it is on the outskirts of Cochabamba City. Gonzalo drives a taxi along the zone's routes. His wife works in a school in the community of Pucarita Chica, 3 hours travel from home, requiring 3 changes of buses. But they have adjusted to the schedule and its requirements and are accustomed to rising very early every day. Their young children remain in the care of their grandmother while both parents work mornings, but they are very young. And the youngest has a harelip which was operated on with foreign assistance but he still requires the care and attention of the parents for his recovery since there were complications. For that reason, Gonzalo's wife had to take a year off from work. Now that their little one is better and has recuperated, both parents are determined to work hard in order to recover from the child's operation. Gonzalo requests a loan to buy replacement parts and to carry out general maintenance on his taxi. He tells us that one of his major dreams is to make enough one day so that his wife can stop working and devote herself 100% to their children.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING REPLACEMENT PARTS AND PERFORMING MAINTENANCE ON HIS TAXI

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
35 years old and welcoming, M. Isaac deals in produce and household items in Wakitaka, Jinja. He has been operating his shop since 2005. He became involved in this business as a means of supplementing the paltry earnings from his prior odd-job business.

Once Isaac came to terms with the lucrative nature of his new-found venture, he changed fully to a produce and household items business. Not one to be thrown out of gear as a result of his naïveté, he persisted through the early unchartered troubled waters. That is the reason he cites for his longevity. With this stock in trade, he has managed to cater for all his children’s educational and other welfare needs.

Isaac’s five-year-old business now brings in a monthly income of 150,000 shillings. He wants to increase this profit in the near future. With this loan he wants to purchase more produce and household merchandise to sell on a bigger scale to his clientele.

In the Photo is M. Isaac in his shop at the left with the Credit Officer in the middle plus M.'s wife at the right.

loans.use: To purchase more fresh produce and new household merchandise to sell

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis is 50 years old and married with five children. For five years, he has earned a living as a greengrocer.   He also earns extra income from renting his residential houses. 

Since joining Faulu Kenya's St. Nicholas group, Francis has saved his profits to support the needs of his family, especially for his children's education until college.  

Francis has requested a loan of KES 40,000 from Faulu Kenya to purchase Irish potatoes and cabbages for resale. He hopes to expand his business and improve his standard of living in the future.

loans.use: To purchase Irish potatoes and cabbages for resale

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric M. R. is thirty six years old, married with a two-year-old child. His business is located in a residential area in Mombasa known as Kisimani.  Mombasa is located in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many many tourist attractions, including the white beaches of the Indian Ocean. 

For the last two years, Eric has been selling cloth and new curtains to the local people. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he faces is delayed payments from his debtors. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He believes that he is friendly and has good community relations.

Eric is using his loan of KES 50,000 to buy more fabric to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase fabric

loans.name: Malizia

texts.en: Malizia H. is a small-business owner and a married woman. She runs a fish-selling business, where she sells both fried and fresh fish. She purchases her fish whole sale from a fish agency or sometimes directly from the fishermen. Since so many people consume fish in the world, there is always a high demand for it. She meets her family's daily demands from the income she earns. She has successfully purchased a plot of land for residential construction in Kigamboni. She needs a loan of 1,400,000 TZS in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Monzer

texts.en:
Monzer is a 28-year-old married man. He's owned a phone sales shop in his town since 2007. His wife helps him manage the household with her work income. He buys all models of mobile phones in addition to buying rechargeable cards. This couple is like the majority of Lebanese couples – they work hard and they collaborate to have a good life and to raise a family.  

Today, Monzer is asking to borrow $1,200 to buy additional rechargeable cards and the latest collections of mobile phones to increase his sales during the summer season. His region is known for its tourist trade and he needs to be ready.

loans.use: To buy additional rechargeable cards and the latest collections of mobile phones

loans.name: Hima Agahikaine Group

texts.en:
Fourteen years is the time Mrs. O. Flavia has spent overseeing her retail business in Hima, Kyenjojo. Since her business got in its stride on a firm footing, she has been able to make the best out of it.

In a month, this focused married mother of four children earns 350,000 shillings. With this money Flavia has managed to cater for all her children’s education needs. She has come to grips with some inevitable business challenges, to wit: high rental charges. She has, however, not lost heart.

The high self-esteem Flavia carries around means she is full of optimism that the future of her business is bright. On that basis she has come to terms with the fact that she needs a loan to be able to revamp her retail business with more merchandise. 

Flavia belongs to a group of nine members who hold each other accountable and insure each other in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her store

loans.name: Godliver

texts.en:
Godliver is 25 years old and married with two children, ages 12 and 6. She has been running a hairdressing salon for two years to earn a living. She was previously selling fish before she ventured into this business. She started the beauty salon because she needed income to support her husband, who is working to cover family expenses. She saves part of her profits with her group in Faulu Kenya, called City Group, who also guarantee her loans. 

Godliver has requested a loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings from Faulu Kenya to buy a steam drier and beauty products such as hair chemicals and braids. She hopes to grow her business and offer her children a better quality life. She desires to see her children happy and grow to be professionals in the future.

loans.use: To buy a steam drier and beauty products

loans.name: Sharif

texts.en:
Many people in Busuyi, Jinja are increasingly adopting an inclination towards M. Sheriff’s fried fish delicacy. The fact that he operates in a fishing neighborhood in Busuyi landing site means he has steady fresh fish supplies any time he wants them. He has sustained his business for a haul of three years. Because of these graces he is enjoying, he foresees a bright future for himself and his family of five children.

Sheriff is a 45-year-old happily-married man. In a month, he says he makes profits to the tune of 100,000 shillings (approximately 50 USD) and he is upbeat that, with this loan, his prospects of further success will rise. With the auspices of this loan he wants to buy fishing nets and a boat.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and a boat

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.es:
Doña Jacinta es una señora de 48 años es viuda ya que hace 10 años que murió su marido y la dejo con  4 hijos de ( 21,19,17) años , pues ella tuvo que trabajar mucho para sacar adelante a sus 4 hijos  por que se quedo viuda muy joven.

Doña Jacinta vive en la ciudad de Cochabamba en la localidad de Chinchilla, en una pequeña casa que le dejo su marido , pues vive con su hijo de 21 años los otros dos se fueron a trabajar a la republica de argentina debido a que tenían muchas necesidades, su principal actividad es la producción de la leche cruda, cuyo producto entrega a una empresa que se dedica a la elaboración de productos lácteos, actualmente cuenta con 5 cabezas de ganado lechero, así como también con la ayuda de su hijo se produce maíz , papa y haba.

El credito que solicita sera utilizado para poder comprar una vaca lechera y de esta manera incrementar su produccion actual de leche. Entre sus sueños y metas es aumentar la producción de leche, y de esta manera aumentar el nivel de ingresos y mejorar el nivel de vida de ella,  de su hijo y de su nieto que apenas tiene 1 año, así como también su meta es realizar una construcción nueva de su casa ya que está muy vieja y tiene pocas habitaciones.
texts.en:
Jacinta is 48 years old and is a widow. Her husband died ten years ago and left her with three children, now aged 21, 19, and 17. She had to work very hard to support her family as she was a widow at such a young age. Jacinta lives in the city of Cochabamba in the Chinchilla neighborhood, in a small house her husband left to her. She lives with her 21-year-old son. The other two children went to work in Argentina out of necessity. Jacinta’s principal occupation is the production of raw milk, which she sells to a business that makes dairy products. Right now, she has five dairy cows. She also grows corn, potatoes, and beans with the help of her son. This loan will be use to purchase another dairy cow to increase milk production. Her goal is to continue to increase production and in this way improve the quality of life for her, her son, and her one-year-old grandson. In the future, she would like to build a new house, as hers is old and has few rooms.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a dairy cow

loans.name: Radhia

texts.en: Radhia C. is an entrepreneurial married businesswoman. She runs a business selling clothes to customers in Kariakoo. She has a clothes shop. She purchases the business items from wholesale shops and sells to retail traders and final consumers. She meets her family's daily needs from her business income and also pays school fees for her children and for business capitalization. Radhia has been in business for five years. She is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 Tanzanian shillings to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Kimbene

texts.en:
Kimbene M. is thirty-five years old and married. He has three children to whom he hopes to give a good education. 

His business is located in Vok, a residential area in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attractions, not to mention the white beaches along the Indian Ocean. 

For the past six years, he has been selling fruit to the local people. He says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge is that fruit prices escalate sometimes, making the fruit very expensive. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of Kes 40,000 to buy more fruit to expand his business. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He is a very hard-working man.

loans.use: To buy fruit to sell

loans.name: Dalmas

texts.en:
Dalmas is a 30-year-old entrepreneur who sells fish. He has four employees and has been in business for nine years. He has four children who go to school. Dalmas is a hard-working and visionary man who also rents out houses in the Kibera slums to earn extra income. He was previously in business in the transport industry.  

He has been saving his money with a group run by Faulu Kenya. He has previously benefited from the group because the members guaranteed his previous loan. 

He has requested a loan of Kes.50, 000 to buy a freezer for preserving fish. He hopes to become a wholesaler in the future.

loans.use: To buy a freezer

loans.name: Hadba

texts.en:
Hadba is a 34-year-old married man and the father of three children. In 2005, he opened a grocery store in his town in the Bekaa Valley. He decided to open his shop because he saw a need for such services in the region. His wife also helps him in his grocery store sometimes and, together, they pay for their family's expenses. He offers foods, such as dairy products, breads, cereals, drinks, canned food, and candies, to his clients. 

Hadba is requesting a loan to purchase merchandise to fill his shop with the needed merchandise to increase his sales and, therefore, his income.

loans.use: To purchase mechandise.

loans.name: Aneth

texts.en: Aneth H. is an entrepreneur and a married woman. She runs a beautiful salon at Kigamboni Ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases her business goods from the wholesale shops at the Kariakoo City Market shopping center. Her business income enabled her to open another business, a cosmetics shop, where she needed to employ two workers to help her with her business. She also meet her daily family demands from her business income. She needs a loan of T.shs 1,200,000 to capitalize the business by buying more goods for her inventory.

loans.use: To buy more goods to expand her business

loans.name: Gazwan

texts.en: Gazwan has worked as a van driver for the past 10 years. He is a 36-year-old married man who has three children. He and his family live in the Bekaa Valley. He offers his transportation services in his town and its surroundings. Gazwan has been a microcredit client for seven years and has always paid on time. Today, once again, he is requesting a new loan to carry out maintenance work on his van to increase its safety features and to save money for his children's school tuition.

loans.use: To do mainenance work on his van.

loans.name: Doreen

texts.en: Doreen is a single woman with one daughter who attends school. She owns a salon and wants to buy cosmetics and a hair dryer, and renovate her space with the ksh. 40,000 loan. Her main challenge is accommodating customers during the high season when it is very busy. She has been in this business for over one year. Previously, she was a student. She rents her home and has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is sending money to her parents to support them.  She joined Yehu because it deals with helping women with small businesses and she is serviced by the Rise and Shine center of the Kisauni branch office.  Some day, Doreen hopes to have a hairdressing school.

loans.use: Cosmetics, hair dryer and renovations to salon

loans.name: Nada

texts.en:
Nada is a 31-year-old married woman and the mother of two children. Four years ago, she decided to open a used clothing and shoe shop in her town in the Bekaa. 

She has already received two micro-loans from A. Majmoua and has consistently paid on time. Her previous loans helped her to improve her business and to purchase merchandise. Her clients like coming to her because she has low prices and offers good quality merchandise. 

Today, Nada is planning on taking another Kiva loan so she can continue to expand her business and purchase more merchandise.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Khoder

texts.en:
Khoder is a 39-year-old married man and father of three children. Three years ago, he decided to open a grocery store in his town in the Bekaa. He offers food products, home cleaning products, breads, cereals, drinks, canned food, bread, candies and other products to his clients. 

Today, for the third time, Khoder is requesting a loan to purchase merchandise to expand his stock, and increase his sales, and, therefore, his income.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise

loans.name: Virginia

texts.es:
La señora Virginia 59 años está casada y tienen 4 hijos (25,21,19 y 17) años , son una familia de escasos recursos económicos ya que ninguno de sus hijos lograron estudiar una carrera profesional , el hijo mayor está casado y tiene 2 hijos , pues no tienen una casa propia y la señora Virginia le ayudo heredándole un pequeño lote de terreno para que puedan construir su casa, todos sus hijos no tienen una vida estable por ejemplo la que tiene 17 años está embarazada sin estar casada.

La señora Virginia vive en la ciudad de Cochabamba en la localidad de A. rancho, su principal actividad es la producción de la leche cruda cuyo producto entrega a una empresa que se dedica a la elaboración de productos lácteos.

El préstamo será destinado para ayudar a su hijo en la construcción de su casa en el terreno que le regalo.
Entre sus sueños y metas es que por los menos sus nietos estudien una cerrera profesional y ayudar a todos sus hijos en lo que ella pueda ya que es una señora de edad
texts.en:
Virginia, age 59, is married and has four children (25, 21, 19, & 17). They are a family of scant economic resources, and none of their children were able to study for a professional career. The oldest child is married and has two children. They do not have their own house. Virginia helped them by passing down to him a piece of land so that they can build their house. None of her children have a stable life. For example, the 17 year old is pregnant, and she is not married. Virginia lives in the city of Cochabamba in the A. Rancho area. Her main activity is the production of raw milk. She delivers her product to a company that makes dairy products. The loan is to help her son build his house on the land gave him.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a house

loans.name: Khalil

texts.en:
Khalil is a 53-year-old man who lives in the Bekaa and is the father of five children. He has run a pickle-processing business since 2007. 

Today, Khalil is requesting a loan to add a water supply to his processing plant. This is his third loan and he has always paid on time. His is planning to improve his business and expand his inventory, which he hopes will help him improve his financial situation.
 
Khalil is special in his work because he does it well and is known for his good production. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face any difficulties. He decided to start his business because he wanted to work independently and has experience in the field. 

In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To install a water supply for his pickle-processing business

loans.name: Anton

texts.en:
Anton U. is an entrepreneur and a married man. He runs a book shop where he sells a variety of books for kindergarten, primary and secondary schools at Yombo Vituka Ward in Dar es Salaam. He purchases the books from the wholesale book shops at the Kariakoo City Market shopping center and sells them retail to customers. 

He is requesting a loan of T.shs 1,200,000 to capitalize the business.

loans.use: To capitalize the business

loans.name: Raimunda

texts.es:
La Señora Raimunda V. tiene 56 años D. edad, es viuda desD. hace 4 años, ella vive en Cochabamba sola con un hijo, Raimunda vive en inmediaciones D. Maica Central, en la periferia D. la ciudad, en una zona agrícola del departamento D. Cochabamba. 

Raimunda es una señora que dedica a la producción D. leche cruda y venta D. quesillos, en el mercado D. la ciudad D. Cochabamba, ella desD. que falleció su esposo se encargo D. todos los gastos del su casa, el cuidado D. su ganado vacuno, la producción D. leche la elaboración D. sus quesillos y con ayuda D. su hijo D. 13 años comercializa los quesillo en el mercado local. La señora Raimunda trabaja todos los días incluso domingos desD. muy temprano y hasta que se acueste el sol, sin descanso. La Señora Raimunda sabe que es esfuerzo es por el bienestar D. su hijo, para que cuando termine el colegio pueda estudiar una carrera, y pueda sostenerse solo luego pues, la señora Raimunda no podrá sostenerlo por mucho tiempo por su avanzada edad.  

La señora Raimunda se apersono a las oficinas en busca D. un crédito para la compra D. alimento balanceado para aumentar la producción D. leche y la elaboración D. quesillo, D. este modo podrá incrementar sus ventas e ingresos y poder ahorrar para luego poder costear los estudios D. su hijo.
texts.en:
Raimunda V. is 56 years old. She has been a widow for four years. She lives in Cochabamba with her only child. Raimunda lives in the Maica Central neighborhood on the outskirts of the city. It is an agricultural zone in the Cochabamba department. Raimunda devotes herself to raw milk production and selling cheese in the market in the city of Cochabamba. Since her husband died, she has been in charge of all of the household expenses, the care of the dairy cows, milk production, and making cheese. Her 13 year old son helps her sell the cheese at the local market. Raimunda works everyday, including Sunday. She starts work very early, and she works without rest until the sun goes down. Raimunda knows that this effort is for her son’s well-being. It is so that he can study a career when he finishes school. That way he will later be able to support himself. Raimunda will not be able to support him for a long time due to her advanced age. Raimunda came to the offices looking for a loan. She wants to buy balanced food to increase milk production and making cheese. That way she will be able to increase her sales and her income. She will be able to save in order to be able to pay her son’s educational expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food for the dairy cows

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 29-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capitA. of Lebanon, with his wife and their child. Ali has owned a barber shop for eight years. He also offers beauty products for men, like gel, hair cleaning products, and more. 

He decided to start his business because he wanted to have an independent workplace. He is speciA. in his work because he knows how to treat his customers and his clients feel comfortable going to his shop because he offers a lot of services. When cleaning the hair, he does head massages. 

His clients are his friends and neighbors. When Ali first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties because he already had faithful customers from his previous job. 

He requested a loan from A. Majmoua to purchase beauty products for his shop. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan. In the future, he plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products for his shop.

loans.name: Adnan

texts.en:
Adnan is a 53 year old man who lives in the Beirut, capital of Lebanon with his wife and their two children. Adnan has owned and operated a coffee shop for five years. He also offers “narguileh” (also known as 'shisha' in Egypt), which is an ancient tradition enjoyed by the people of the Middle East. A tall (or short) water pipe is used to smoke fruit-flavored tobacco. Narguileh is enjoyed in cafes across the Middle East and is beginning to gain popularity in the US, Europe, and other countries. 

He decided to start his business because he used to work as a waiter and gained experience from his previous jobs. He is special in his work because he is well located, and he does his best to meet his clients’ demands and offer them the best. His clients are his friends, neighbors and tourists. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of clients, because he wasn’t known by the public, but he knew how to enlarge his network. 

He has requested a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase an espresso machine. Adnan has been a microcredit client for seven years now and has always paid on time. His previous loans allowed him to continually improve his business by purchasing the necessary tools to have a nice coffee shop.

loans.use: To purchase an espresso machine

loans.name: Isaac Jose

texts.es:
l señor Isaac Jose, es un señor de 47 años viudo que se dedica a la confección de  prendas de vestir para mujer, tiene 2 hijas, de 18 y 15 años. El señor Isaac vive por inmediaciones del mercado La Pampa, un mercado popular de la ciudad de Cochabamba en la provincia Cercado.

Jose quedo viudo desde hace 1 año, el tenia una familia muy feliz y un negocio, que le permitía dar a su familia el sustento necesario, pero su esposa enfermo de tuberculosis, y no pudo recuperarse pues además tenia diabetes, a pesar de los cuidados y tratamiento que recibió, ambas enfermedades la consumieron y por complicaciones la esposa de Jose falleció dejando muy  triste a su familia; por factores hereditarios la hija mayor de Jose también tiene diabetes muy avanzada, y aun que esta con tratamientos, se indispone constantemente, pues ellos con cuentan con muchos recursos, entonces ella no recibe un tratamiento adecuado, por eso la familia esta muy pendiente de ella. Los tres únicos integrantes de la familia, se apoyan mutuamente, mientras el padre confecciona las prendas de vestir, las hijas se encargan de comercializar los productos, son una familia ejemplar, organizada, que día a día lucha por superar la muerte de su madre y sobrellevar con las necesidades.

Jose solicito el crédito, para la compra de material para la confección, tela e hilos, el es muy conocedor de su negocio y tiene el sueño de que su hija se recupere y puedan controlar la enfermedad que padece, pues  en Cochabamba los medicamento que necesita son muy costosos, y para poder someterla a un tratamiento Jose necesita incrementar mas sus ventas y doblar esfuerzos en su trabajo.
texts.en:
Isaac Jose is a 47 year old widower. He makes women’s clothes. He has two daughters, 18 and 15. Isaac lives in the neighborhood of the La Pampa market. This is a popular market in the city of Cochabamba in the Cercado province. Jose became a widower a year ago. He had a very happy family and a business, which allowed him to support his family. But, he wife became ill with tuberculosis, and she could not get better. She also had diabetes. In spite of the care and treatment she received, both illnesses consumed her. Due to complications, Jose’s wife died leaving her family very sad. Jose’s oldest daughter, due to hereditary factors, also has very advanced diabetes. Even though she receives treatments, she is constantly unwell. They do not have many resources, so she does not receive adequate treatment. Therefore, the family is very devoted to her. The three members of the family mutually support each other. While the father makes the clothing, the daughters sell the products. They are an exemplary family, and they are organized. They fight day to day to overcome the death of their mother and to pull through with the necessities. Jose is asking for a loan to buy material for making clothes. He will buy fabric and thread. He is well known in his business. He has the dream that his daughter will recover and they will be able to control the illness she suffers from. In Cochabamba the medicine she needs is very costly. In order to be able to get her a treatment Jose needs to increase his sales and double his work efforts.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fabric and thread, etc.

loans.name: Nahi

texts.en:
Nahi is a 23-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon. Nahi has owned a barber shop for almost two years now. He sells beauty products. 

He is special in his work because he knows how to treat his customers and his clients feel comfortable going to him because he offers a lot of services. Most importantly, he is good in his work and is aware of the new hair style fashions. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties beause he already had faithful customers from his previous job. He decided to start his business because he gained experience and wanted to have an independent workplace. His clients are his friends, neighbors and tourists. 

He has requested a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase beauty products and make some décor changes. This is his second loan and he has always paid on time.

loans.use: To purchase beauty products and make some décor changes

loans.name: Augenia

texts.en:
Augenia B. is an entrepreneur and a married woman. She runs a business selling fruit, potatoes, onions and green vegetables in Makangarawe Ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases her business goods from the food market in Buguruni and in the Temeke City Market shopping center. She also runs a business raising poultry, which she developed with the income from her other business. She meets her family's daily needs from her business income. 

She is requesting a loan of T.shs 1,400,000 to improve her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Abd Allah

texts.en:
Abd Allah is a 35-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Abd Allah has been selling frames and paintings for fifteen years. He likes art and offers a big variety of paintings from all different genres. He paints, but doesn’t sell his paintings because he likes it and it is his hobby. 

He has requested a loan from Al Majmoua to purchase paintings and frames. Abd Allah has been a micro-credit client for nine years and has always paid on time. His previous loans allowed him to improve his sales and expand his stock.

His clients are his friends, neighbors and tourists. When he first started his business, he didn’t have a lot of clients because he wasn’t known by the public, but he knew how to enlarge his network.

loans.use: To purchase paintings and frames

loans.name: Martina

texts.en:
Martina L. M. is fifty-seven years old, married, and has six children between 26 and 39 years old. Her business is located at Mukhonje, a busy market in Kakamega. She owns a restaurant in which she serves the local people porridge, chapati and doughnuts. She says that this business is profitable and her major challenge is that there are so many people in the area doing the same kind of business, so customers are not loyal because they are spoiled by choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of Kes 70,000 to buy flour, rice, sugar and cooking oil to expand her business. She hopes to open a big "hotel" (a restaurant) in future. She is very hard-working and ambitious.

loans.use: To buy flour, cooking oil, sugar.

loans.name: Elvira Nicolasa

texts.es:
Elvira C. P. a sus 57 años, muchos habitantes del Municipio de Soledad la conocen por su dedicación al negocio, y es porque 10 lavadoras de su propiedad, rotan día a día  entre las familias de su barrio y los alrededores en condición de alquiler, así a cada ama de casa se le facilita lavar, mientras realizan otras actividades domésticas y todo a un precio justo. Ella inició con 3 máquinas y ahora tiene 10, pero necesita  reemplazarlas porque ya terminaron su ciclo de vida útil; este es justamente la necesidad que resolverá con el crédito solicitado por valor de $2.000.000, ella va a comprar 4 lavadoras y así mejorará el servicio a sus clientes. 
Elvira  siempre ha sido negociante, en el año 1999  tenia dos colmenas en el mercado en un sitio llamado Miami y en el año 2001 montó un gimnasio en su vivienda con el dinero de la venta de sus dos colmenas, pero solo duró 2 años, porque su casa es pequeña y ella quería generar mayores ingresos; fue así como se dedicó a ofrecer el servicio de alquiler de lavadoras entre sus conocidos y familiares cercanos que gradualmente van recomendado otros referidos. 
Tener negocio ha sido muy importante para la vida de Elvira y la de su familia, porque con ello pudo apoyar los estudios profesionales de su hijo que ya terminó administración de Empresas.
Su meta mas importante es montar una sucursal en una vía principal  del barrio Santuario, un barrio al sur de Barranquilla, para obtener mas ingresos; mas adelante ella también quiere asociarse con sus hijos en otro negocio:  Servicios de motocarros para transporte de los habitantes de barrios del Municipio de Soledad.
Su desafío actual es la selección de los clientes a los cuales va a prestarle el servicio, porque puede correr el riesgo de que les roben sus lavadoras, por eso trabaja especialmente con sus vecinos, propietarios de viviendas y referidos principalmente y controla en tiempo de devoluciones de las màquinas con mucho rigor.
texts.en:
Elvira C. P., 57, is well known by people of the town of Soledad for her dedication to her business. Elvira has 10 washing machines that she rents to the households in her neighborhood and those nearby. This helps the householders to get their washing done while they attend to other chores, and at a fair price. Elvira started out with three machines and now has ten. However, she needs to replace them as they have worn out. With this loan of 2,000,000 pesos, she will buy four new machines, which will improve her service to her customers. Elvira has always been a businesswoman. In 1999, she had two stalls in the market in a place called Miami, and in 2001 she built a gym in her home with the money from selling the stalls. This business lasted only two years because her house was small and she wanted to make more income. At this point, she started the washing machine rental business among her friends and family, who gradually recommended it to others. Having a business has been important to Elvira and her family, as it has enabled her to pay education expenses for her son who has now finished a course in Business Administration. Elvira’s most important goal is to open an office on a main street of Santuario, a neighborhood in the south of Barranquilla, to increase her earnings. In the future, she would like to partner with her children in a taxi business in the town of Soledad. Her biggest challenge now is selecting good clients, as there is a risk that someone will steal the washing machines. For this reason, she works with neighbors, property owners and people with references, and she is careful that the machines are returned on time.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy four washing machines to rent

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
Nuru is a widowed woman with nine children between the ages 37 and 30, and eight grandchildren. With the ksh. 30,000 loan, she hopes to purchase cement, sand, stones, and paint to repair houses for renting. She has been in the rental housing business for three years and hopes to install piped water and electricity some day. She also has a small grocery stall where she sells vegetables and food. 

She decided to work with Yehu because she wanted to uplift her family life. Her greatest monthly expense is food. She says that, back when she got married, she used to stay with her husband at his shamba (farm) in the country and would get food easily. Life in the city is different because everything costs money.

loans.use: To purchase cement, sand, stones and paint for repairing her rental house.

loans.name: Jared

texts.en:
Jared is 33 years old and married with two children who are in school. He runs a retail shop where he sells household goods, cereals and plastics. He has been in this business for five years and has two employees. He also runs a taxi business to earn extra income. He was previously employed as a security guard in a mercury trading company before he started this business. He saves part of his profit with his savings group called Mapema. 

He has requested a loan of kes 40,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy rice, sugar and cooking fat for his inventory. He hopes to buy a plot and build his family a house in the future.

loans.use: To add to his stock of rice, sugar and cooking fat.

loans.name: Mwanamgeni

texts.en:
Mwanamgeni is a married pregnant woman with three children, who are 10, 9 and 8 years old and attend school. She also takes care of her sister's niece. She has been an Islamic teacher to 3rd grade children for the past six years. 

With this ksh. 10,000 loan, she hopes to construct a new classroom. She also sells food and snacks for additional income. Her greatest challenge is that, at times, parents don't pay school fees. 

She lives in her family house and has piped water, but no electricity. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and food. She hopes that she can support her children through 8th grade.

loans.use: Construct a new classroom

loans.name: Serah

texts.en:
Serah is a hardworking and faithful widowed lady with four children who are finished with school. She sells building materials, such as sand, bricks and ballast, to earn a living. She also earns extra income from renting her residential houses. She was employed in a meat canning company before she realized the need for more money because she is the breadwinner of the family. 

She saves her money with her group members from Faulu Kenya on a weekly basis, which enables the group members to access loans. 

She has requested a loan of kes 30,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy sand and ballast. She plans to buy a lorry to make transportation of building materials easier in the future.

loans.use: To buy sand and ballast.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Abdallah

texts.en: Abdallah P. is a married small-businessman with two schoolchildren. He runs a foodstuffs shop at Tandika ward in Dar es Salaam. He purchases and sells a variety of foodstuffs including rice, maize flour, wheat flour, beans, groundnuts, sugar and millet. He purchases from the wholesale shops at Kariakoo city shopping center and sometimes direct from the suppliers. He sells to customers at retail. He manages to meet his family's daily demands and business capitalization from his business income. He needs a loan of Tshs 1,200,000 to boost the business.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Felistus

texts.en: Felistus is a single lady.  She has been doing carpentry for six years.  Since she became a member of Faulu Kenya, she has been saving her money with a group called Masachu Ushindi. She has benefited from the group because the members guarantee each other when a member takes out a loan.  She has requested a loan of Kes. 30,000 to buy timber and cushions to make furniture. Felistus is a hardworking lady who hopes to have a big furniture store in the future.

loans.use: To buy timber and cushions

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kigumba Bakyara Group

texts.en:
T. Mathias is an ever-optimistic 42-year-old teacher who is married and the father of four. He operates a modest retail business in Kigumba-Rwensiga, Kyenjojo district. With a business longevity spanning seven years, he has reason to smile. With this business he has managed to significantly sustain and improve on his family’s welfare.

To all appearances, Mathias’ future business prospects look rosy. With close to 50,000 shillings coming in every week from his business, he envisions an even greater profit once he can obtain this loan. He anticipates being in a position to buy more merchandise for his retail shop once he acquires this loan.

Mathias belongs to a group of eleven members who hold each other accountable and insure each other in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store

loans.name: Unidas Para Triunfar 4 Group

texts.en:
Victoria is the coordinator of her group Unidas Para Trinfar (United to Triumph), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santiago, a large city known for its tobacco production, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a single mother with her three children.

Victoria is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza and is excited to have access to capital at low interest rates. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling accessories by purchasing watches, chains and other assorted accessories to sell to customers in her community. She will use the profits to invest in materials to remodel her home. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase watches, chains and accessories

loans.name: Kennedy

texts.en: Kennedy is a 38-year-old married man with two children who go to school.  He sells vegetables, fruits and grains and has one employee.  He has been in the business for four years. He was previously employed as a cashier in a town restaurant.  He also does farming to earn a living.  Since he is the breadwinner in his family, he works hard to meet his family’s needs.  Kennedy is a member of Nakaso group in Faulu Kenya where he saves his money.  He has requested a loan of Kes. 30,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy fruits, vegetables and grains.   For this loan, his group members have guaranteed him. He hopes to be a major supplier of farm produce.  He plans to venture into zero grazing in the future.

loans.use: To buy grains, fruits and vegetables

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Daraay Xandiar Caapy Group

texts.fr:
Daraay Xandiar Caapy est une association regroupant des femmes d’une classe d’alphabétisation mise en place en 2008 par une ONG très populaire au Sénégal. Après  leur formation, elles ont reçu un soutien de 100 000 FCFA pour qu’elles les fructifient, en application de leur formation, en activité génératrice de revenus. Elles sont toutes dans  le commerce et vendent divers produits. 
Ainsi, le groupe est  composé de Madame Nogaye N. vendeuse de jus locaux (jus bissap et jus pain de singe) la présidente, Madame Adama F. la trésorière vendeuse également de jus locaux, Madame Fatou G. vendeuse de tissus du genre indigo (thioupe), Madame Soda G. qui vend de l’huile de palme et pâte d’arachide et de Madame Souado S. vendeuse de bois de chauffage et du charbon de bois.
texts.en:
Daraay Xandiar Caapy is an association bringing together women from a literacy class set up in 2008 by a very popular ONG in Senegal. Once finished with their training, the women received support worth 100,000 francs CFA, so that they may flourish when applying their training to income-generating businesses. They all work in commerce and sell a variety of goods. The group is composed of Ms. Nogaye N., the president and a vendor of local juices: bissap juice (made from hibiscus flowers) and pain de singe juice (made from the fruit of the baobab tree); Ms. Adama F., the treasurer and a vendor of local juices also; Ms. Fatou G., a vendor of indigo-type cloth (thioupe), Ms. Soda G., who sells palm oil and peanut butter; and Ms. Souado S., a vendor of firewood and charcoal.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Developing their respective businesses

loans.name: Ann

texts.en: Ann is a hardworking married lady with three children who are in school. She runs a tailoring shop to earn a living. She makes a range of clothing with a variety of designs per her customers' requests.  Ann is a professional seamstress who has a loyal customer base because of her good service.  She has been in the business for 10 years and has two employees. She saves her money with her group in Faulu Kenya named Miracle, which guarantees loans to its members.  She has many customers and she is unable to meet their demands due to her limited capital. Therefore, she requested a loan of Kes 27,000 from Faulu Kenya to buy more fabric.  She hopes to grow her business and stabilize her income in the future.

loans.use: To add to her stock of fabric

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en: Tatu M. is a married small-businesswoman. She runs a foodstuffs shop at Mbagala ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases her business goods from the wholesale shops at Kariakoo city center business market. Goods sold include beans, maize flour, rice, wheat flour, cooking oil and sugar. She manages to meet her family's daily demands from her business income including paying school fees. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,200,000 to capitalize the business by buying more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses is a 21-year-old married man who has three children who go to school.  He has been doing photography for three years.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, his living standard has improved. This is because he has been saving his money with a group called Nrbi in Faulu Kenya.  This savings has helped him improve his business. He has requested a loan of Kes 30,000 from Faulu Kenya, which has been guaranteed by the group members.  He plans to use this loan to buy cameras.  He hopes to get more customers in the future.

loans.use: To buy cameras

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mtendeje

texts.en: Mtendeje I. is a small entrepreneur and a married woman. She runs a business as a food vender at Kigamboni Island in Dar es Salaam. She prepares and sells both cooked and fried food to customers. She also sells some soft drinks. She purchases her business goods from the foodstuff shops at Kariakoo and other shops around. The business income enabled her to buy a plot of land at Kigamboni for residential house building. She needs a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Félix Noel

texts.es: El joven Félix T. es originario del municipio de El Sauce, inició su negocio brindando servicio de transporte a los pobladores a través de un tricitaxi que le financió Ceprodel en el año 2004 con el fin de generar sus propios ingresos, desde entonces este ha sido su negocio principal para llevar el sustento a su familia donde tiene cinco años de trabajar con Ceprodel y tener su propio negocio, le han otorgado 10 créditos para el mantenimiento del mismo y para ir poco a poco mejorando su vivienda en la que habita con su mamá y hermanos.
texts.en:
El joven Félix T. es originario del municipio de El Sauce, inició su negocio brindando servicio de transporte a los pobladores a través de un tricitaxi que le financió Ceprodel en el año 2004 con el fin de generar sus propios ingresos, desde entonces este ha sido su negocio principal para llevar el sustento a su familia donde tiene cinco años de trabajar con Ceprodel y tener su propio negocio, le han otorgado 10 créditos para el mantenimiento del mismo y para ir poco a poco mejorando su vivienda en la que habita con su mamá y hermanos.

Translated from Spanish by Alex J, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de madera para reparación de la vivienda

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Capital to invest in empanadas, soft drinks, and other food items.

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es:
La señora Maribel M. C. tiene 25 años y actualmente vive en Cochabamba en la zona sur, en una Zona conocida como Maica Kenamari, junto a su esposo y sus dos hijos. 

Maribel  es productora de leche cruda con la cual elabora yogurt y vende este producto en los diferentes mercados locales de la ciudad de Cochabamba. Maribel se dedica a la producción de leche cruda hace más de 6 años. Su esposo trabaja en el sector de mantenimiento de maquinaria en un Taller Industrial ubicado en Cochabamba, esta actividad la realiza por casi 3 años y según sus jefes es una persona trabajadora, puntual y en conclusión un excelente empleado.

Maribel solicita el crédito para poder comprar más vacas lecheras y así poder incrementar sus ingresos y poder agrandar el número de vacas que tiene. El mayor sueño de Maribel es poder incrementar su producción de leche y sus ingresos de forma que junto a su esposo puedan comprar una casa donde vivir solos junto a sus hijos puesto que por el momento viven en casa de la madre de su mujer.
texts.en:
Maribel M. C., 25, lives in the southern part of Cochabamba in an area known as Maica Kenamari with her husband and two children. Maribel is a raw milk producer that she uses to make yoghurt for sale at various Cochabamba markets. Maribel has been a dairy farmer for over 6 years; her husband works as a machine maintenance man at an industrial workshop in Cochabamba, a job he’s had for 3 years. According to his supervisors, he is a hard-working, punctual, excellent employee. Maribel is asking for funds to buy more dairy cows in order to increase earnings and herd size. Her greatest dream is to increase milk production and her income so that, together with her husband, they can buy a house where they can live with their children by themselves; they currently share his wife’s mother’s house.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Ayim Group

texts.en:
Mary A. is a hard-working and honest baker and the group leader of 'A.' group. She has been in the bakery business for the past seven years, and currently has one oven which she says is not enough to meet the demand from her customers. As a result she is looking for support to expand her business to the level that she can own 5 gas ovens which will enable her to meet the high demand from her customers and also support her children's education to the university level.

'A.' group is comprised of 5 members and has been in existence a little  over one year. All members say they are happy to be together and with hard work and financial support, each hopes to own a big business where they can retail their products. They are excited to be taking this loan to enable them to accomplish their dream.

loans.use: Purchase bags of flour for baking

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Martha Lesbia

texts.es: La Sra. Martha Lesbia R. es originaria de la comarca La Palma a unos ocho km del municipio de El Sauce, su negocio consiste en una pequeña pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación donde ofrece abarrotería en general a los pobladores de dicha comarca, tiene cinco años de tener su propio negocio y dos años de trabajar con Ceprodel donde le han otorgado tres créditos para invertirlo en la compra de productos como arroz, frijoles, azúcar, jabón, aceite y otros, con el objetivo de ampliar su negocio y así generar más ingresos a su familia.
texts.en:
La Sra. Martha Lesbia R. es originaria de la comarca La Palma a unos ocho km del municipio de El Sauce, su negocio consiste en una pequeña pulpería ubicada en su casa de habitación donde ofrece abarrotería en general a los pobladores de dicha comarca, tiene cinco años de tener su propio negocio y dos años de trabajar con Ceprodel donde le han otorgado tres créditos para invertirlo en la compra de productos como arroz, frijoles, azúcar, jabón, aceite y otros, con el objetivo de ampliar su negocio y así generar más ingresos a su familia.

Translated from Spanish by Alex J, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de arroz, azúcar, aceite, jabón, golosinas, pan, frijoles, ect.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To install two telephone booths.

loans.name: Rio De Oro Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Rio D. Oro inicia su cuarto ciclo con 23 socias. Las socias son del barrio D. Río Seco.
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como L. venta D. cereales, abarrotes en general, animales menores, artesanía, ropa, frutas, verduras y L. mayor parte D. las socias se dedican a brindar el servicio D. bordado.
Como es el caso D. L. Señora Fabiana que es casada, tiene 43 años y 3 hijos, Fabiana tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes en general, golosinas, bebidas, actividad que realiza todos los días. Además Fabiana se dedica al bordado D. correas, bolsas, vinchas, servicio que brinda a una empresa exportadora. Su préstamo será invertido en L. compra D. azúcar, jabón y detergentes. Los sueños D. Fabiana son estudiar cosmetología, surtir su tienda y que sus hijos estudien en L. universidad.
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 300 soles, 600 soles, 900 soles haciendo un total D. 10,950 soles.
texts.en:
The “Rio D. Oro” (River of Gold) communal bank, composed of 23 members from the Rio Seco neighborhood, is in its 4th loan cycle The members are involved in a variety of commercial activities such as: cereal sales, general grocery sales, small farm animal raising, sale of crafts, clothing, fruits and vegetables; most of the members proviD. embroidery services. Such is the case of Fabiana, 43. She’s married, has three children and runs a grocery store from her home; she sells assorted groceries like snacks and beverages every day. In addition, Fabiana embroiders belts, purses, and hair bands for an exporting firm. She will use the funds to buy sugar, soap and detergents. Fabiana’s dream is to become a cosmetologist, stock her store and that her children go to university. The members need various loan amounts: 300, 600, and 900 soles totaling 10,950 soles.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap and detergents.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To restock her store with the essentials

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella C. is a married small-businesswoman. She runs a business sewing and selling clothes to customers at Kigamboni ward in Dar es Salaam. She makes different kinds of clothes for men, women, girls, boys and school uniforms according to orders requested. She bought two or three sewing machines and employed one worker who assists her in the business. She has been in the business for five years. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,400,000 to boost the business.

loans.use: To boost the business

loans.name: Carmen Margarita

texts.es: La Sra. H. A. Carmen Margarita vive en el distrito de Santiago, junto a sus dos  hijos de 10 y 3 años de edad. Trabaja como obrera de campo en el fundo Ica Pacific desde hace 2 años. Tiene casa propia la cual la esta construyendo. Solicita financiamiento para  terminar de construir su vivienda. Su sueño es poder brindar una mejor calidad de vida para su familia. La Sra. Carmen agradece el apoyo que le podamos brindar a tarves de este financiamiento.
texts.en:
Mrs. Carmen Margarita H. A. lives in Santiago with her two children who are 10 and 3 years of age, respectively. She has worked as a field hand for Ica Pacific farming estate for the past two years. She is building her house and needs funds to complete it. Her dream is to provide a better quality of life for her family. Carmen is grateful for whatever support we can offer via this financing.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For home improvements.

loans.name: Juan Leonard

texts.en: Juan Leonard is part of the Unidos para el Triunfo community bank, which translates to “United for Triumph”. He is 45 years old and lives in Cusco with his spouse. Together, they have two children, ages 19 and 17. Juan Leonard makes his living as an employee of the state, but also owns a small business outside of the city raising and selling cuy, or guinea pigs. In this region, guinea pigs are considered a delicacy and are usually roasted and served whole during lunchtime. Juan Leonard currently owns 300 guinea pigs that he plans on selling. Juan Leonard will use a Kiva loan to help grow his small business raising guinea pigs, and will use the loan to buy feed for the animals. He is appreciative of, and thankful for, the loan and promises to pay the monthly payments on time.

loans.use: To buy guinea pig feed

loans.name: Gilma De Jesús

texts.es: La Sra. Gilma M. es originaria de la comarca Las Pilas a unos 9 km del municipio de El Sauce, su negocio consiste en la venta de ropa nueva tanto para damas, caballeros y niños donde tiene 10 años de dedicarse a este negocio lo que le ha permitido mejorar su vivienda y sacar poco a poco adelante a sus cuatro hijos. Tiene dos años de trabajar con Ceprodel donde le han otorgado cuatro créditos consecutivos para la compra de pantalones de mujer, de varón, camisas, blusas con el fin de satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
La Sra. Gilma M. es originaria de la comarca Las Pilas a unos 9 km del municipio de El Sauce, su negocio consiste en la venta de ropa nueva tanto para damas, caballeros y niños donde tiene 10 años de dedicarse a este negocio lo que le ha permitido mejorar su vivienda y sacar poco a poco adelante a sus cuatro hijos. Tiene dos años de trabajar con Ceprodel donde le han otorgado cuatro créditos consecutivos para la compra de pantalones de mujer, de varón, camisas, blusas con el fin de satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.

Translated from Spanish by Alex J, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de pantalones de mujer, hombre, blusas, camisetas.

loans.name: Thelma Janneth

texts.es: La Sra. N. es originaria del municipio de El Sauce, su negocio consiste en la venta de ropa nueva para damas, caballeros y venta de cosméticos donde tiene ocho años de dedicarse  a este oficio lo que le ha permitido sacar adelante a sus dos hijos como madre soltera. Tiene tres años de trabajar con Ceprodel donde le han otorgado tres créditos, este último para la instalación de un kiosko donde ofertará productos básicos para el hogar como una nueva opción para generar ingresos para su familia.
texts.en:
La Sra. N. es originaria del municipio de El Sauce, su negocio consiste en la venta de ropa nueva para damas, caballeros y venta de cosméticos donde tiene ocho años de dedicarse a este oficio lo que le ha permitido sacar adelante a sus dos hijos como madre soltera. Tiene tres años de trabajar con Ceprodel donde le han otorgado tres créditos, este último para la instalación de un kiosko donde ofertará productos básicos para el hogar como una nueva opción para generar ingresos para su familia.

Translated from Spanish by Alex J, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Compra de arroz, frijoles, azúcar, gaseosas, cosméticos y golosinas

loans.name: Ebenezer 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Fauna plans to use this loan to invest in her ambulatory business selling clothing by purchasing pants, sheets and children's clothing. Her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) generally. Her group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santiago where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure as a single mother with her five children.

Fauna is excited to be taking her second loan  with Esperanza  after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She will use the profits to invest in her home by purchasing a fan as well as saving towards growing her business. Fauna is the coordinator of her group, "Ebenezer". She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy pants, sheets and children's clothing to sell

loans.name: Asha

texts.en: Asha R. is an entrepreneurial married small businesswoman. She runs a café at Mbagala Machinjioni in Dar es Salaam. She prepares and sells both fried and cooked food to customers. She purchases the business goods from the foodstuff shops at Kariakoo city market business center and from the surrounding shops. She also runs a shop selling tires to customers which was started with her business income. She employs two workers to assist her running the business. She is requesting a loan of 1,200,000 Tanzanian shillings to capitalize the business.

loans.use: To capitalize the business

loans.name: Maguette

texts.fr: Maguette D. est une femme de 46 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de DANKH SENE depuis 7ans et demi et a une bonne expérience en matière de crédit pour en avoir 15 fois de suite. Elle fait de l'embouche bovine, son nouveau prêt lui permettra d'acheter une paire de bœufs et de l'aliment de bétail afin d'engraisser les bêtes et de le revendre au bout de 4 à 5 mois. Et les bénéfices générés par son activité lui permettront de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Maguette D. is a 46 year old woman, she is married and a mother providing for five children. She has been a member of the “Banc Villageois” of Dankh Sene for seven and a half years. She has a large experience in terms of borrowing having benefited of 15 consecutive loans. She raises cattle. Her new loan will allow her to buy a pair of oxen and cattle feed to fatten them up and resell them after 4 or 5 months. The profits engendered by this activity will enable her to participate in the improvement of her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a pair of oxen

loans.name: Riqueza Group

texts.es:
